questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized fatigue for the past 3 months. During this time, his grades have declined in his college courses because he has had difficulty focusing on assignments and sometimes sleeps in class. He no longer plays the drums for his band and has stopped attending family events. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he describes his mood as “ok.” He has a flat affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. His speech is slow in rate and monotone in rhythm, and his thought process is organized. He has no delusions or hallucinations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as escitalopram are the first-line treatment for MDD because of their efficacy and relatively limited side-effect profile. Patients taking SSRIs may not see a reduction in symptoms until 4–6 weeks after therapy is initiated. If no improvement is seen after this time, it is reasonable to increase the dose, switch therapy to another SSRI, or switch therapy to another drug class (selective serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, atypical antidepressants, or trazodone). Tricyclic antidepressants and MAO inhibitors are usually reserved as third- or fourth-line treatment for refractory MDD. Psychotherapy should also be initiated, as the combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy is more efficacious than either one alone.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance may be indicated if patients present with mild dysphoria and/or other depressive symptoms, but do not meet criteria for the diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) or another disorder. This patient clearly meets criteria for MDD, which requires treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer that can be used for major depressive disorder (MDD) with mixed features as well as for bipolar disorder. This patient does not exhibit any manic symptoms (i.e., DIG-FAST), so lithium would not be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Phenelzine is a nonselective monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) that is rarely used to treat major depressive disorder because of its serious side effects (hypertensive crisis if co-ingested with tyramine-containing foods, serotonin syndrome, and risk of fatal overdose). A safer and better-tolerated antidepressant would be preferred for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor that can be administered via transdermal patch for the treatment of major depressive disorder. However, it is not used as first-line therapy because of its serious side effects (hypertensive crisis if co-ingested with tyramine-containing foods, serotonin syndrome, and risk of fatal overdose). A safer and better-tolerated antidepressant would be preferred for this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Diazepam is a benzodiazepine primarily used to treat anxiety or alcohol withdrawal, and would not be used as first-line treatment of depression. In this patient, the sedative effects of diazepam would worsen his symptoms of hypersomnia and psychomotor retardation.

G) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) and third-line agent for the treatment of major depressive disorder. It is not first-line because of its less favorable side effect profile (sedation, anticholinergic effects, and risk of fatal arrhythmia from overdose), although side effects remain rare. Though many patients take TCAs without experiencing adverse effects, these drugs would only be indicated if first- and second-line therapy fails.

H) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that is primarily used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Risperidone can be used in conjunction with other medications as first-line treatment for depression with psychotic features. It can also be used to augment antidepressant therapy or as monotherapy in unipolar depression without psychotic features if first-line antidepressant therapy has had an inadequate effect. This patient has no evidence of psychosis and first-line antidepressant monotherapy has not yet been administered.
questions.hint: This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (anhedonia, sleep changes, fatigue, diminished concentration and cognition, psychomotor slowing) for ≥ 2 weeks, which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD). The presence of anhedonia or depressed mood is necessary to meet the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of sadness that started 6 weeks after her daughter was born. She gave birth 9 months ago via vaginal delivery. Since then, she has not returned to work. Although her daughter usually sleeps through the night, the patient has difficulty staying asleep. She appears agitated and says that she sometimes feels frustrated with her daughter when she cries. She is easily distracted from normal daily tasks. She used to enjoy cooking but only orders delivery or takeout now. She says that she always feels too exhausted to cook and does not feel hungry much anyway. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes. The child was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has had no medical problems. The patient has no contact with the child's father. She is not sexually active. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is 157 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 47 kg (105 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is alert and cooperative but makes little eye contact. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

To meet the criteria for a diagnosis of persistent depressive disorder, a patient must have a depressed mood for at least 2 years. This patient has only had symptoms of depression for 7.5 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Postpartum psychosis most commonly develops within the first 2–4 weeks after childbirth and usually manifests with depressed mood, insomnia, and psychomotor agitation. However, this patient does not have psychotic features (i.e., hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and/or bizarre behavior). Patients with postpartum psychosis may also experience suicidal ideation or thoughts of harming the baby. Occasionally feeling frustrated with one's crying child is a normal response and does not indicate postpartum psychosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Postpartum blues are mild depressive symptoms (e.g., tearfulness or sadness) that may last up to 2 weeks following delivery. This patient presents with severe depressive symptoms that started 6 weeks after delivery and have lasted > 7 months.

D) INCORRECT:

Adjustment disorder is a maladaptive emotional (e.g., anxiety, depression) or behavioral response to a stressor, lasting ≤ 6 months following resolution of the stressor. This patient has had symptoms for > 7 months following her delivery, and she meets the criteria for a different psychiatric diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient meets all diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). This condition is diagnosed in individuals who experience ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (SIGECAPS) that last for ≥ 2 weeks and cause clinically significant distress or impaired functioning in important areas of life. At least one of the symptoms must be depressed mood or anhedonia. Diagnostic criteria specify that symptoms should not be due to the effects of psychoactive substances or organic diseases, or be superimposed onto or caused by a psychotic disorder. Furthermore, there should be no history of a manic or hypomanic episode.

The DSM-5 criteria for MDD with peripartum onset specify that symptoms must begin either during pregnancy or up to 4 weeks after birth. Other diagnostic criteria consider symptom onset up to 1 year postpartum. Treatment for both types of MDD involves antidepressants (e.g., an SSRI), lifestyle changes, and/or psychotherapy. Special safety considerations should be taken in prescribing medications to pregnant and lactating individuals.
questions.hint: This patient has been experiencing insomnia, anhedonia, exhaustion, poor concentration, and decreased appetite for > 7 months.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. The patient had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he told her that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. The patient is concerned about his memory lapses. He wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He often feels too tired to leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time as well as psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Attention, concentration, and short- and long-term memory are impaired. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is indicated in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer dementia (AD). Patients with AD can present with impairment of daily life and, especially in early stages, show symptoms of depression. However, the onset of AD is usually insidious, with progression over ∼ 8–10 years. The memory of recent events is typically the cognitive domain affected first in patients with AD. For this reason, patients are typically not oriented to person, place, or time. Also, unlike this patient who is concerned about his memory loss, patients with AD are often not aware of their cognitive deficits.

B) CORRECT:

This patient meets 5 (anhedonia, sleep disturbance, diminished cognition, psychomotor changes, and low energy) out of the 9 diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). In patients with late-life depression, cognitive deficits may resemble dementia (i.e., pseudodementia). Compared to patients with other types of dementia, patients with pseudodementia are more likely to be aware of and concerned about memory impairment. Cognitive deficits in MDD typically have a sudden onset and manifest after the mood symptoms (e.g., this patient lost interest in playing the piano several months ago). Treatment of the underlying depression, e.g., with SSRIs such as citalopram, may lead to remission of the depression and reversal of the cognitive deficits. In older patients in particular, different causes of dementia must be considered if memory impairment persists after appropriate treatment and an improvement in depressive symptoms.

See “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet drugs such as aspirin may be considered in patients with vascular dementia. This type of dementia may present with abrupt cognitive decline and stepwise deterioration. This patient has risk factors for vascular dementia such as hypertension and advanced age. However, his loss of interest, sleep disturbance, and psychomotor retardation cannot be explained by this diagnosis and warrant a different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

A cerebral shunt is the treatment of choice for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). While NPH typically manifests with impaired memory, other typical findings such as incontinence and ataxic gait are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

E) INCORRECT:

Memantine can be used in addition to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors in patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer dementia or vascular dementia. This patient's memory deficits could be explained by either of these dementia types, and depressive symptoms may occur in early dementia. However, his cognitive deficits are more likely to be caused by pseudodementia.
questions.hint: This patient's cognitive deficits are likely caused by pseudodementia.

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation because of extreme irritability, fatigue, and loss of appetite for 3 weeks. Five months ago, his grandfather, whom he was very close to, passed away from chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He used to enjoy playing soccer but quit his soccer team last week. When he comes home from school he goes straight to bed and sleeps for 11–12 hours each night. He previously had good grades, but his teachers report that he has been disrespectful and distracted in class and failed an exam last week. He tried alcohol twice at a party last year and he has never smoked cigarettes. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he avoids making eye contact but cooperates with the exam. His affect is limited and he describes an irritable mood. He is easily distracted and has a difficult time focusing for an extended conversation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Substance use disorder is characterized by a craving for, development of tolerance to, and difficulties in controlling the use of a particular substance or a set of substances, as well as withdrawal syndromes upon abrupt cessation of substance use. Heavy substance use and subsequent intoxication and withdrawal may cause an unstable mood with depression and irritability. However, this patient's substance use history is very mild, so it would not explain his current presentation.

B) CORRECT:

To diagnose major depressive disorder (MDD), 5 or more of the diagnostic criteria for MDD have to be fulfilled for at least 2 weeks at a time, one of which must be anhedonia or depressed mood. The 4 criteria not present in this patient are depressed mood, feelings of worthlessness or disproportionate guilt, psychomotor agitation or retardation, and suicidality. In children and adolescents, the depressed mood may be less marked and MDD may resemble attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, which manifests with difficulties concentrating and irritability.

The first-line treatment in moderate to severe adolescent MDD is either psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) or pharmacotherapy with fluoxetine.

C) INCORRECT:

To diagnose attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), symptoms of hyperactivity, impulsivity, or inattention must be present before the age of 12 years and must last for at least 6 months. While this patient has concentration issues, he lacks other features of ADHD and his problems only became apparent 3 weeks ago at the age of 16.

D) INCORRECT:

To diagnose adjustment disorder with depressed mood, symptoms of depression have to occur within 3 months in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., death of a loved one, serious illness, ending of a relationship). Full criteria for other psychiatric conditions, such as major depressive disorder, are typically not met. This patient's symptoms developed approximately 4 months after the death of his grandfather, are more severe than in adjustment disorder, and fulfill the criteria for another disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

To establish the diagnosis of depression with atypical features, patients must present with two or more of the following features: increased appetite or weight gain, increased sleep, leaden paralysis (arms and legs feel heavy), and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity (i.e., rapidly perceiving and overreacting to social rejection). Additionally, they have to show mood reactivity (i.e., their mood brightens in response to positive events), which clearly differentiates atypical depression from major depressive disorder. While this patient presents with hypersomnolence, he rather has decreased appetite and shows no leaden paralysis, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with bipolar disorder present with alternating periods of elevated mood (mania or hypomania) and depression, interspersed with periods of normal mood and functioning. While this patient has had 3 weeks of multiple depressive symptoms, he lacks a history of a manic/hypomanic episode.

G) INCORRECT:

To diagnose persistent depressive disorder, the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder must be present for more than a year in children, or more than two years in adults. Since this patient presents with symptoms for only 3 weeks, it is too early to consider this diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient has had 3 weeks of multiple depressive symptoms: anhedonia, loss of appetite, decreased concentration, decreased energy, and hypersomnolence.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of depressed mood for 6 months. He works as a store manager and cannot concentrate at work anymore. He experiences daytime sleepiness and fatigue because he repeatedly wakes up at night and has difficulties falling asleep again after 4 AM. He reports no longer taking pleasure in activities he used to enjoy, such as going fishing with his son. He has decreased appetite and has had a weight loss of 5 kg (11 lb) over the past 6 months. He does not have suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. He is divorced and lives with his girlfriend. He drinks several alcoholic beverages on the weekends. He is diagnosed with major depressive disorder and a trial of sertraline is suggested. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Postural hypotension is a potential side effect of tricyclic antidepressants (TCA), but not a common side effect of SSRIs. TCAs block alpha-1 receptors on the blood vessels, which can cause vasodilation, hypotension, and impaired baroreflexes.

B) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome is a very rare side effect of monotherapy with SSRIs, as is the case in this patient. Instead, this syndrome is more likely to occur with simultaneous use of two or more serotonergic medications (e.g., MAO inhibitor and SSRI). Serotonin syndrome can also occur when switching the medication regimen from one serotonergic drug class to another serotonergic drug class (e.g., from MAO inhibitor to SSRI). For that reason, the first drug should be tapered or even stopped for some days before introducing the new agent.

C) CORRECT:

Up to half of the patients taking SSRIs experience sexual dysfunction, including delayed ejaculation and other conditions such as anorgasmia and decreased libido. SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can remit spontaneously within 2–8 weeks. However, if sexual dysfunction persists, decreasing the SSRI dose (in patients who are on high doses and in remission), augmentation with sildenafil, or switching to a non-SSRI antidepressant that does not cause sexual dysfunction (e.g., bupropion, mirtazapine) may be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants have anticholinergic effects, which can induce tachycardia, arrhythmia, intestinal ileus, and a decrease in bladder detrusor muscle contraction that can lead to urinary retention. However, anticholinergic effects are not a common side effect of SSRIs.

E) INCORRECT:

While some studies have shown that antidepressants can increase the risk of suicide in patients under 24 years of age with pre-existing (!) suicidal ideation in the first weeks of treatment, there is no evidence that SSRIs or tricyclic antidepressants increase suicidality in nonsuicidal individuals of this patient's age group. This rather rare side effect is assumed to be caused by the sequential onset of these drug's effects: while SSRIs can increase a patient's motivation to initiate and perform self-directed activities (including self-harming behavior) already shortly after initiating treatment, the onset of the mood-lifting effects can be delayed by 2–4 weeks. Since this patient is 58 years old and is not suicidal, another side effect should be considered.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive crisis is a potential side effect of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO inhibitors) in combination with the consumption of tyramine-containing products (e.g., aged cheese, smoked meat, wine). Since tyramine is metabolized by MAO, the inhibition of MAO can lead to the accumulation of tyramine. Excess tyramine can induce elevated norepinephrine release. This leads to the activation of alpha-1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction and subsequent hypertension. Patients are therefore advised to follow a low-tyramine diet during therapy with MAO inhibitors.

G) INCORRECT:

Priapism is a potential side effect of serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitors (SARIs) like trazodone. It is assumed that blocking of alpha adrenergic receptors on smooth muscle cells in penile arteries leads to prolonged vasodilation and thus prolonged blood flow into the penis. While priapism can sometimes occur as a side effect of sertraline, it is not nearly as common as another side effect of SSRIs.
questions.hint: This patient meets criteria for major depressive disorder, as evidenced by his depressed mood, anhedonia, fatigue, poor concentration, sleep disturbances, decreased appetite, and weight loss. Sertraline belongs to the class of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI), the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty sleeping and increasing fatigue. Over the past 3 months she has been waking up early and having trouble falling asleep at night. During this period, she has had a decreased appetite and a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. Since the death of her husband one year ago, she has been living with her son and his wife. She is worried and feels guilty because she does not want to impose on them. She has stopped going to meetings at the senior center because she no longer enjoys them and because she feels uncomfortable asking her son to give her a ride, especially since he has been under a great deal of stress lately. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (110 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is tired and has a flattened affect. Cognition is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Recommend relocation to a nursing home

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychiatric hospitalization is indicated in patients with severe functional impairment and those at imminent risk of harming themselves or others. This patient's MDD may be severe enough to require hospitalization, but to establish this, she should first be properly assessed.

B) INCORRECT:

Notification of adult protective services becomes necessary if abuse and/or neglect are suspected. This patient's BMI is normal and physical examination has not revealed signs of malnourishment, dehydration, or physical abuse.

C) INCORRECT:

Recommending relocation to a nursing home could be indicated if the patient's son was unable to properly care for his mother or if there were signs of abuse and/or neglect (e.g., severe dehydration, low BMI), but this is not the case in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Cognitive-behavioral therapy can be helpful as an adjunct therapy in patients with MDD, because it can teach stress management, relaxation, and coping techniques, and may improve everyday functioning. However, patient assessment has to be completed beforehand.

E) INCORRECT:

Family therapy may be helpful in this patient with MDD as an adjunct therapy, especially since there are familial conflicts stressing her. However, it is not the next best step and patient assessment has to be completed beforehand.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient may benefit from mirtazapine therapy, a second-line treatment for MDD that would also cause her to gain weight and help improve insomnia due to its sedative effect. However, this patient requires proper assessment prior to initiation of antidepressive therapy.

G) CORRECT:

Suicide screening and assessment is indicated for all patients who display symptoms of MDD. The physician should inquire about suicidal ideation, intent, and plans. Appropriate management depends on the severity of these symptoms and ranges from close observation, psychotherapy, and pharmacotherapy to the involvement of the family and involuntary hospitalization.
questions.hint: This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (anhedonia, insomnia, loss of appetite, fatigue, and feelings of guilt) for ≥ 2 weeks, which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because she cries frequently and refuses to get out of bed. Over the past 3 weeks, she has been feeling sad and tired most of the time. She has difficulty staying asleep at night and often wakes up early in the morning. After losing her job as a waitress 1 month ago, she has been feeling guilty for not contributing to the household income. She would like to find a new position but is unable to decide “what to do with her life.” She was diagnosed with anorexia nervosa at age 18 and has gone to psychotherapy several times since then. Her weight had been stable for the past 5 years; however, within the past 3 weeks, she has had a 2.8-kg (6.2-lb) weight loss. She would like to regain some weight. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and currently weighs 47 kg (104 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 58/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and flat affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following drugs is most likely to address both this patient's mood disorder and her desire to gain weight?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is used to treat MDD and is commonly used in patients who wish to stop smoking. Although bupropion may alleviate the symptoms of depression in this woman, patients with eating disorders are at higher risk of seizure when taking bupropion because it decreases the seizure threshold. Furthermore, bupropion is associated with the least amount of weight gain among antidepressants, which would not be suitable for this patient based on her low BMI, history of anorexia, and desire to gain weight.

B) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer that can be used for MDD with mixed features as well as for bipolar disorder. A side effect of lithium is weight gain, which could potentially benefit this patient, who has a desire to gain weight. Lithium can also be used in patients with MDD to augment an antidepressant if first-line therapy has had an inadequate effect. Some studies also indicate that lithium reduces the risk of suicide in patients with MDD. This patient has not yet started antidepressant treatment, and there are no signs of suicidal ideation or manic symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, are the preferred pharmacotherapy in MDD. However, common side effects of SSRIs include changes in appetite and weight (anorexia or weight gain). Among the SSRIs, fluoxetine is most commonly associated with weight loss. Because this patient has a desire to gain weight, a different antidepressant would be more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

In addition to MDD, this patient has a low BMI, significant recent weight loss, and a history of anorexia nervosa. Therefore, she would benefit from treatment with mirtazapine, an antidepressant that would also cause her to simultaneously gain weight during treatment. Furthermore, mirtazapine has sedative properties, which may alleviate her insomnia, and therefore her fatigue.

E) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine is a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) commonly used as an alternative to the first-line treatment to treat depression. However, venlafaxine would not address her desire to gain weight.

F) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine is commonly used as adjunct therapy in patients with MDD who also have anxiety-related or psychotic symptoms. A common side effect of olanzapine is weight gain, which would benefit this patient. However, this patient has neither anxiety-related nor psychotic symptoms, and olanzapine is not indicated as a monotherapy for MDD.

G) INCORRECT:

Although topiramate is typically used as an anticonvulsant, it can also be used in patients with eating disorders. Topiramate is only indicated to reduce weight gain associated with binge eating and impulsive behavior. It plays no role in the treatment of depressive disorders or anorexia nervosa.

H) INCORRECT:

Phenelzine is used in the treatment of atypical depression, of which this patient has no symptoms (e.g., brightening of mood in response to positive events, hypersomnia, increased appetite). This patient would benefit from an antidepressant therapy that is indicated for MDD and can help her to gain weight.
questions.hint: This patient presents with depressed mood, fatigue, insomnia, feelings of guilt, and weight loss over a period > 2 weeks, the combination of which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD). The preferred drug for MDD in this patient causes sedation, which can be beneficial in patients with insomnia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of difficulty sleeping and worsening fatigue. During this time, he has also had difficulty concentrating and remembering tasks at work as well as diminished interest in his hobbies. He has no suicidal or homicidal ideation. He does not have auditory or visual hallucinations. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and flat affect with slowed thinking and speech. The physician prescribes sertraline. Three weeks later, the patient comes to the physician again with only minor improvements in his symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Augment with phenelzine and continue sertraline
Augment with aripiprazole and continue sertraline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

It can take 4–6 weeks for patients to feel any improvements of symptoms after beginning antidepressant therapy and 6–12 weeks for the medication to take full effect. This patient has only been on sertraline for 3 weeks. For patients who have little improvement on sertraline after 4–6 weeks, it would be reasonable to trial another selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, such as fluoxetine.

B) INCORRECT:

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is appropriate in depressive patients with severe suicidality or refusal of food resulting in malnutrition. This patient has no evidence of suicidality or malnutrition that would warrant ECT at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Sertraline has a half-life of 26 hours. Therefore, only daily dosing is required to reach therapeutic levels. Increasing the frequency of dosing would not increase the efficacy of this medication.

D) INCORRECT:

It can take 4–6 weeks for patients to feel any improvements of symptoms after beginning antidepressant treatment and 6–12 weeks for the medication to take full effect. This patient has only been on sertraline for 3 weeks. It would be appropriate to switch to an serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, such as duloxetine, if this patient received no relief or only partial relief of his symptoms after 6-12 weeks on sertraline.

E) INCORRECT:

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), such as phenelzine, should never be combined with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome. Additionally, MAOIs are not first-line treatment options for major depressive disorder due to their high side effect profile. However, they can be used as monotherapy in patients who have failed multiple other antidepressant trials.

F) INCORRECT:

It can take 4–6 weeks for patients to feel any improvements of symptoms after beginning antidepressant treatment and 6–12 weeks for the medication to take full effect. This patient has only been on sertraline for 3 weeks. Augmentation with a second-generation antipsychotic such as aripiprazole would be appropriate if this patient only received partial relief of his symptoms after 6–12 weeks on sertraline.

G) INCORRECT:

It can take 4–6 weeks for patients to feel any improvements on an antidepressant and 6–12 weeks for the medication to take full effect. This patient has only been on sertraline for 3 weeks. It would be inappropriate to switch to another antidepressant at this time. If this patient was experiencing intolerable side effects to sertraline (e.g., sexual dysfunction), it would be appropriate to change medication to bupropion at this point.

H) CORRECT:

This patient meets criteria for major depressive disorder given his depressed mood, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as sertraline are recommended first-line medications but may require 4–6 weeks for patients to notice improvements and 6–12 weeks for the medication to reach full effectiveness. Therefore, this patient should continue sertraline with close follow-up before switching to a new treatment.

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son after he found her trying to hang herself from the ceiling because she felt that she was a burden to her family. Her family says that for the past 2 months she has had no energy to leave her room, has been sleeping most of the day, has lost 10 kg (22 lb), and cries every day. She was diagnosed with breast cancer that has metastasized to the liver 4 months ago. She moved in with her son and daughter-in-law shortly after the diagnosis. She initially underwent chemotherapy but discontinued the treatment when the metastases spread to the spine and brain. Her life expectancy is 1–2 weeks and she is currently receiving home-hospice care. Her only current medication is a fentanyl patch. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 46 kg (101.4 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows slow speech, a flat affect, and depressed mood. Which of the following treatments is most likely to provide the greatest benefit to this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Psychostimulants (e.g., methylphenidate), despite adverse effects such as anorexia, nausea, and weight loss, should be considered for terminally ill patients with severe acute depression and a very limited life expectancy (i.e., days to weeks) and/or those at risk of suicide, because these drugs are fast-acting (response often within 1–2 days). In many cases, psychostimulants are combined with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and phased out gradually over a period of weeks if the patient lives long enough to benefit from the effects.

B) INCORRECT:

Megestrol acetate is an appetite stimulant that can be used in adults with cancer-related anorexia or cachexia. Although it would be beneficial for improving this patient's appetite and low weight, it would not help in the treatment of her MDD, which should first be treated considering her recent suicide attempt and short life expectancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although fluoxetine and other selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are first-line drugs in the treatment of MDD, the response to treatment generally takes ∼ 4 weeks. However, this terminally ill patient with a short life expectancy has severe depression and recently attempted suicide. Although an SSRI should be considered, she would initially benefit most from a faster-acting treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is effective in patients with MDD and may be offered to cancer patients to evaluate beliefs and thoughts as a means of processing the diagnosis and developing skills for coping with it. However, CBT is a long-term treatment that, especially in cancer patients, should be combined with pharmacologic therapy. Additionally, in this terminally ill patient with a short life expectancy who has MDD and a recent suicide attempt, a faster-acting treatment modality is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is a drug approved for MDD, but it only takes effect after 1–2 weeks of administration. This terminally ill patient with a short life expectancy has severe depression and recently attempted suicide; she requires faster-acting treatment. Moreover, bupropion is contraindicated in patients who are at risk of seizures, as it decreases the seizure threshold. This patient has been diagnosed with brain metastases, which make her prone to convulsions. Lastly, bupropion would prevent weight gain, which is not desirable in a patient with cancer cachexia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (depressed mood, anhedonia, hypersomnia, psychomotor retardation, feelings of worthlessness, suicidal attempt) for ≥ 2 weeks, which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD). Her short life expectancy and suicide attempt should be considered in her treatment plan.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Paroxetine therapy was initiated 6 months ago for a major depressive episode. He now feels much better and says he is delighted with his newfound energy. He gets around 8 hours of sleep nightly and his appetite has increased. He has been able to resume his job at a local bank. He also exercises at the gym 3 times a week and enjoys reading books again. Over the past two years, he has also had two episodes of depressed mood, insomnia, low energy, and loss of appetite that lasted 6–8 weeks, for which he received treatment. During these episodes, he interrupted his job training because he had trouble concentrating on his classes and he stopped going to the gym with his friends. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 128/66 mm Hg. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he describes his mood as "good.” In addition to regular follow-up, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Switch from paroxetine to venlafaxine therapy
Switch from paroxetine to valproic acid therapy
Switch from paroxetine to cognitive behavioral therapy
Switch from paroxetine to lithium therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors should always be tapered off at some point. However, only two additional months is too short of a time frame for this patient with recurrent depressive episodes, and premature cessation could lead to a recurrence of depressive symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Paroxetine therapy should be continued for at least 1–3 years in this patient with major depressive disorder because he has already had three major depressive episodes. Antidepressant therapy is divided into three phases: acute phase, continuation phase, and maintenance phase. The acute phase refers to the initial therapy following diagnosis. In the continuation phase of treatment, patients remain on their therapeutic regimen for 16–36 weeks (4–9 months) after achieving remission. Patients who have a sustained response to continuation pharmacotherapy for at least 6 months are recommended to transition to maintenance therapy if at least one of the following indications is present: three or more major depressive episodes, severe episodes (e.g., suicidal ideation), and/or risk factors for recurrence (e.g., onset ≤ 18–21 years). The total duration of maintenance phase treatment is patient-dependent and must be reevaluated regularly; it can be lifelong. Ideally, pharmacotherapy is combined with cognitive-behavioral therapy.

Side effects of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors include sexual dysfunction, serotonin syndrome, and an increased risk of suicidal ideation, particularly in adolescents and young adults; careful monitoring is essential.

C) INCORRECT:

Switching to a different antidepressant, such as venlafaxine, would be indicated if the patient did not respond sufficiently to paroxetine after 4–6 weeks of treatment or in the case of unacceptable adverse effects. This patient responded well to paroxetine therapy and has not reported side effects. Changing to another selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor or a different class of antidepressants is therefore unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Antidepressants such as paroxetine should never be discontinued abruptly in patients with major depressive disorder, but rather tapered off over weeks or months to avoid antidepressant discontinuation syndrome or a relapse of depression. Moreover, this patient responded well to paroxetine therapy and has not reported side effects. Discontinuation is not recommended at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with depressive symptoms should be thoroughly screened for bipolar disorder before beginning treatment and monitored for new-onset insomnia and irritability after initiating selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy. Paroxetine can precipitate a shift to hypomania or mania in patients with bipolar disorder. While this patient has become more active and his mood is elevated, he does not have a history of hypomania or mania and lacks characteristic symptoms (i.e., decreased need for sleep, flight of ideas, distractibility, and/or excessive involvement in risky activities). Therefore, a switch to valproic acid is unnecessary.

F) INCORRECT:

Continuation of paroxetine for 6 months is the correct approach in patients who are in remission and have had only one depressive episode. This patient is currently in remission, but he has had several depressive episodes and therefore requires a different management approach.

G) INCORRECT:

Switching to cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) could be considered if the patient does not respond sufficiently to paroxetine after 4–6 weeks of treatment or has unacceptable adverse effects. This patient responded well to paroxetine therapy and has not reported side effects such as sexual dysfunction. While CBT should be considered as an adjunct therapy, switching to CBT alone would not be appropriate.

H) INCORRECT:

Lithium can be combined with paroxetine in patients with treatment-resistant depression. This patient has responded well to monotherapy, so lithium augmentation is unnecessary.

I) INCORRECT:

Patients with depressive symptoms should be thoroughly screened for bipolar disorder before beginning treatment, and they should be monitored for new-onset insomnia and irritability after initiating selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy. Paroxetine can precipitate a shift to hypomania or mania in patients with bipolar disorder. This patient has become more active and his mood is elevated, but he does not have a history of hypomania or mania or symptoms specific to it (i.e., decreased need for sleep, flight of ideas, distractibility, and/or excessive involvement in risky activities). Therefore, a switch to lithium is unnecessary.
questions.hint: This patient presents with remission of symptoms after paroxetine therapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her mother because she refuses to get out of bed and spends most days crying or staring at the wall. Her symptoms started 3 months ago. The patient states that she is very sad most of the time and that none of the activities that used to interest her are interesting now. She sleeps more than 10 hours every night and naps during the day for several hours as well. Her mother, who cooks for her, says that she has been eating much larger portions than she did prior to the onset of her symptoms. The patient moved in with her mother after splitting up with her boyfriend and being expelled from her doctoral program at the local university, and she feels guilty for not being able to support herself. Two months ago, the patient was diagnosed with atypical depression and prescribed fluoxetine, which she has taken regularly since that time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and flat affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following would be contraindicated as the next step in management?

choices.text: Taper fluoxetine and switch to desipramine
Taper fluoxetine and switch to venlafaxine
Taper fluoxetine and switch to sertraline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although increasing the dose of fluoxetine adds to the risk of side effects, it may improve this patient's symptoms. While an increased dose is not contraindicated, switching to a different class of antidepressants is more common to avoid side effects if there has been insufficient improvement with the initial dose.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), such as desipramine, are rarely used as first- or even second-line antidepressants because of their extensive side-effect profile (e.g., sedation, orthostatic hypotension, anticholinergic syndrome) and the risk of lethal overdose. However, switching to a TCA is a potential treatment option if initial monotherapy with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) has been unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

Changing to a selective serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) such as venlafaxine is a reasonable treatment option if initial monotherapy with an SSRI fails. Before initiating SNRI therapy, blood pressure control should be considered due to its adverse effect of hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

If selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor monotherapy alone is not effective in patients with major depressive disorder, cognitive behavioral therapy can be substituted or added to improve symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Atypical antidepressants, such as bupropion, are typically prescribed as monotherapy because combination treatment may increase the incidence of side effects and lower patient adherence. Bupropion reduces the seizure threshold and is contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of seizures (e.g., e.g., history of a seizure disorder, anorexia/bulimia). In patients without such contraindications, augmentation with a low dose of bupropion is a reasonable treatment option if there is no response to initial monotherapy with an SSRI.

F) CORRECT:

Treatment with a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI), such as phenelzine, is contraindicated in patients taking selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) because of an increased risk of serotonin syndrome. Antidepressants should generally be discontinued at least 2 weeks before initiating therapy with MAOIs, but fluoxetine should be discontinued at least 5 weeks prior because of its long half-life. Although MAOIs are particularly effective at treating symptoms of atypical depression, such as increased sleep and increased appetite with subsequent weight gain, they are considered a third- or fourth-line treatment because they have numerous drug interactions and side effects (e.g., hypertensive crisis with ingestion of foods containing tyramine).

Many treatment options are available for patients with major depressive disorder who do not respond to first-line monotherapy with an SSRI (e.g., other SSRIs, atypical antidepressants, tricyclic antidepressants, MAOIs, cognitive behavioral therapy). When choosing an alternative, comorbidities, patient preference, and cost should all be considered.

G) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as sertraline are the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder but they may cause sexual dysfunction and increase the risk of bleeding and serotonin syndrome. However, switching to another SSRI is a reasonable treatment option if initial monotherapy with one type of SSRI fails.
questions.hint: This step could result in fever, cardiovascular abnormalities, and myoclonus.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fatigue, difficulty sleeping, and feeling sad. She has been unable to concentrate recently and is no longer interested in spending time with her friends. She has a history of anorexia nervosa, for which she attends weekly psychotherapy. She has had a persistently decreased appetite for 3 months. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and flat affect. Treatment with a drug is begun that treats both her depressed mood and her decreased appetite. An overview of a noradrenergic synapse is shown. The prescribed drug most likely has which of the following labeled mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Inhibition of α2-adrenergic receptors (as well as 5-HT2 receptors, 5-HT3 receptors, and H1 receptors) is the mechanism of action of mirtazapine. These mechanisms increase the synaptic release of norepinephrine and serotonin. Although mirtazapine is typically considered a second-line antidepressant for major depressive disorder, it stimulates appetite and can cause weight gain, which is desirable in a patient with comorbid anorexia nervosa.

Mirtazapine also causes sedation (which may be useful in patients with comorbid insomnia disorder) and dry mouth.
Image Description:

Antidepressants work by increasing levels of serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT; green circles), norepinephrine (NE; purple circles), or dopamine within the synaptic cleft, which can be achieved by:

1. Increasing neurotransmitter release
– Mirtazapine increases the release of NE and 5-HT into the synaptic cleft by blocking the presynaptic alpha-2 adrenergic receptors. It also inhibits postsynaptic 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors, reducing some of the side effects of increased serotonergic activity (e.g., nausea, sleep disturbances).

2. Decreasing neurotransmitter breakdown
– Monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors decrease the breakdown of NE and 5-HT.

3. Inhibiting the reuptake of neurotransmitters and thereby increasing their concentration within the synaptic cleft
– Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) block serotonin transporters (SERTs), inhibiting the reuptake of 5-HT.
– Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) and selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SSNRIs) block SERTs and norepinephrine transporters (NETs), inhibiting the reuptake of 5-HT and NE respectively.
– Bupropion inhibits the reuptake of NE by blocking NETs.
– Serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitors (SARIs) block postsynaptic 5-HT2 receptors and weakly inhibit the reuptake of 5-HT (by blocking SERTs at higher doses).

B) INCORRECT:

Activation of α2-adrenergic receptors is the mechanism of action of clonidine, α-methyldopa, and brimonidine. Clonidine is used to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder and hypertensive urgency, while α-Methyldopa is used to treat hypertension during pregnancy. Brimonidine is used to treat open-angle glaucoma. None of these drugs is indicated in major depressive disorder or anorexia nervosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of monoamine oxidase (along with inhibition of sodium channels and GABA transaminase) is the mechanism of action of valproic acid. This drug is used to treat seizures, migraines, and bipolar disorder but is not indicated in major depressive disorder or anorexia nervosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of monoamine oxidase (MAO) is the mechanism of action of MAO inhibitors (e.g., phenelzine). This group of drugs reduces the breakdown of intrasynaptic amine neurotransmitters (e.g., serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine). MAO inhibitors are rarely used as first-line or second-line antidepressants because of their potentially severe side effects, which include hypertensive crisis and serotonin syndrome. They are most commonly used to treat atypical depression and anxiety and would not be the most appropriate choice for a patient with major depressive disorder and anorexia nervosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of norepinephrine reuptake is part of the mechanism of action of serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), and bupropion. SNRIs and TCAs (which also inhibit serotonin reuptake) can be used to treat major depressive disorder but are not the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for a patient with comorbid anorexia nervosa. Bupropion (which also inhibits dopamine reuptake) reduces the seizure threshold and is therefore contraindicated in individuals with increased seizure risk, which include patients with anorexia nervosa.

F) INCORRECT:

Activation of norepinephrine reuptake is a mechanism that is of interest for the treatment of depression. However, there are no approved substances that currently target this mechanism.

G) INCORRECT:

Activation of norepinephrine receptors is a mechanism that is of interest for the treatment of depression. However, there are no approved substances that currently target this mechanism.

H) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of norepinephrine receptors is a mechanism that is of interest for the treatment of depression. However, there are no approved substances that currently target this mechanism.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of anorexia nervosa and symptoms of major depressive disorder (e.g., depressed mood, fatigue, sleep disturbances, anhedonia). Mirtazapine is an antidepressant that also stimulates appetite.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of unexplained weight loss over the past 8 months. During the examination, he tells the physician that he has been having marital issues with his wife. He filed for bankruptcy 2 months ago for a business he had owned with his brother until his brother died of skin cancer a year ago. He has tried to hide his financial issues from his wife and explains that he is feeling increasingly desperate and no longer “sees the light at the end of the tunnel.” He worries about finances and what would happen if he developed cancer like his brother, and then cannot fall asleep. In the morning, he feels tired and finds it hard to start the day. The patient says the symptoms began a few months after his brother's death and then, “Everything started to fall apart. I can't concentrate, my wife will probably leave me soon, and now I have lost the business.” Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?

choices.text: "I cannot imagine how hard this must be for you. You say you no longer see the light at the end of the tunnel. Are you having thoughts of suicide?"
"Considering what you have been going through, it is absolutely normal to feel that way. You will see that things will become easier for you over time!"
"It sounds like you are depressed, but before we begin treatment for depression, I would like to evaluate you for any underlying conditions that may be causing your mood changes."
"This is obviously a very difficult time for you and it would be normal to turn to certain substances when you are feeling this way. Would you be willing to provide a urine sample for testing?"
"Losing your brother must have been extremely hard for you. Would you be willing to speak with a grief counselor?"
"After the death of your brother, it is even more important to stay close to your family. What do you think about starting to attend family therapy with your wife?"

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Through this reaction, the physician shows empathy and specifically asks about suicidal ideation. Assessing a patient's suicide risk is the most important diagnostic step for any depressed individual. If the patient confirms that he is having suicidal ideation, the physician should also ask the patient if he has thought of a means of suicide (suicidal plan), assess the degree to which he intends to put the plan into action (suicidal intent), and evaluate whether additional risk factors for suicide completion are present (e.g., possession of a firearm, personal and family history of prior suicide attempts). If the patient is suicidal, they should be admitted to the hospital. Treatment of a major depressive episode often requires a combination of antidepressants, psychotherapy, and lifestyle changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Through this reaction, the physician minimizes the patient's symptoms. Although it could be normal for the patient to occasionally have some of his symptoms (e.g., depressed mood, decreased sleep, decreased concentration) as a part of grief, it is not normal to have them on a persistent basis or have unexplained weight loss over 8 months. Moreover, by saying, “You will see that things will become easier for you over time!" the physician is making promises that cannot be guaranteed.

C) INCORRECT:

Depression can be caused by organic conditions (e.g., hypothyroidism, CNS neoplasm, Parkinson disease), and it is necessary to evaluate patients with features of depression for organic disease. However, since depression can be life-threatening, there is something more pressing that the physician should first address with this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Depression can be caused by a substance use disorder, and it is necessary to evaluate any patient with features of depression for a substance use disorder. However, it would be inappropriate to perform a urine toxicology screen before first directly asking the patient about substance use and examining the patient for signs of a substance use disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

A referral to a grief counselor is appropriate for the management of grief, which is caused by the death of a loved one and can present with symptoms such as a depressed mood, disturbed sleep, and decreased concentration, as seen here. However, the symptoms of grief tend to occur in waves (grief pangs), decrease over time, and are not associated with functional impairment or feelings of desperation. This patient's presentation is consistent with a major depressive episode and cannot be treated by grief counseling alone. Moreover, even in patients with grief, it is important to first ask a specific question in order to differentiate normal from pathological grief.

F) INCORRECT:

The patient said that he has been having marital issues with his wife, so seeing a family therapist with his wife could be beneficial. However, since depression can be life-threatening, there is something more pressing that the physician should first address with this patient.
questions.hint: This patient, who presents with a depressed mood, sleep disturbance, fatigue, diminished concentration, and weight loss over a period > 2 weeks, is experiencing a major depressive episode.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1 is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 5-day history of anxiety and tearfulness. According to her mother, the patient “has not been herself” since the delivery of her 1-week-old son. “She spends hours sitting next to the crib to make sure the baby is still breathing and barely gets any sleep. She also doesn't let me hold the baby because she thinks I might drop him.” The patient has a good appetite and is breastfeeding without any issues. The patient's sister has a history of bipolar disorder. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an involuting uterus consistent in size with her postpartum date. Mental status examination shows no evidence of homicidal or suicidal ideation. During the examination, the patient asks the physician if there is anything wrong with her. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "You most likely have the postpartum blues, which are very common after delivery. Let's schedule a follow-up appointment in 10 days."
"You most likely have the postpartum blues, which are very common after delivery. It takes some time to adjust to this new responsibilty, but you will feel better soon."
"You most likely have postpartum depression, which affects almost 1 in 10 women after delivery. I recommend we initiate antidepressant therapy."
"You most likely have postpartum depression, which affects almost 1 in 10 women after delivery. I recommend we initiate cognitive behavioral therapy."
"Given your family history, you most likely have postpartum psychosis. I'm afraid we will have to hospitalize you."

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has postpartum blues, which manifest with mild depressive symptoms within one week of delivery. The postpartum blues are seen in up to 85% of women following delivery and typically resolve spontaneously within 2 weeks. Therefore, providing reassurance and making sure a family member can support the mother until the symptoms subside is sufficient. However, since the postpartum blues can sometimes progress to major depressive disorder with peripartum onset (i.e., if at least 5 of the clinical features of MDD are present and persist for more than 2 weeks), it is important to schedule a follow-up meeting approx. 10 days after the diagnosis of postpartum blues in order to reassess the patient's mental state.

See “Differential diagnosis of peripartum mood disturbances” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Tearfulness, anxiety, and insomnia within 1 week of delivery, without other depressive symptoms (e.g., change in appetite, suicidal ideation), indicate the postpartum blues. Although postpartum blues typically resolve spontaneously within 2 weeks, some patients develop postpartum depression. Therefore, another response by the physician is more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Postpartum depression can manifest within 4 weeks of delivery with symptoms such as tearfulness, insomnia, and anxiety. However, the diagnosis of postpartum depression can only be made when at least 5 of the clinical features of MDD are present, which is not the case in this patient. Furthermore, the diagnosis of postpartum depression requires that symptoms persist for at least 2 weeks, whereas this patient's symptoms only started 5 days ago.

D) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy is an effective treatment option for postpartum depression, which manifests within 4 weeks of delivery with symptoms such as tearfulness, insomnia, and anxiety. However, the diagnosis of postpartum depression can only be made when at least 5 of the clinical features of MDD are present, which is not the case in this patient. Furthermore, the diagnosis of postpartum depression requires that symptoms persist for at least 2 weeks, whereas this patient's symptoms only started 5 days ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Postpartum psychosis typically develops within 2 weeks of delivery and can manifest with features such as anxiety, insomnia, and tearfulness. Furthermore, this patient's family history of bipolar disorder places her at increased risk of postpartum psychosis. However, she lacks other characteristic findings, such as hallucinations, delusions, and paranoia. Moreover, most patients with postpartum psychosis are hospitalized because they have considered harming themselves or their children, which is not the case here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with anxiety, tearfulness, and insomnia without changes in appetite or breastfeeding. These symptoms have developed within 1 week of delivery.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of sadness and lack of energy. Six weeks ago, she gave birth to a healthy girl at term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient says that she feels overwhelmed by the responsibility to care for a newborn and struggles to sleep at night even when her daughter is sleeping. She feels guilty and anxious because she is too tired to give attention to her daughter. Her appetite is decreased, but she breastfeeds the baby without any problems. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears disheveled and makes poor eye contact. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows a labile affect with no evidence of homicidal or suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as paroxetine, are the first-line treatment for patients with MDD. In addition, SSRIs are approved for patients with postpartum depression as they are safe to use while breastfeeding. It may take 4–6 weeks to see any symptom reduction; if no improvement is seen after this time, it is reasonable to increase the dose, transition to another SSRI, or switch to a different drug class. Psychological and behavioral therapy should also be recommended for this patient, as the combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy is more efficacious than either one alone.

B) INCORRECT:

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) can be used to treat severe cases of MDD with peripartum onset (e.g., for patients who have suicidal or homicidal intent, refuse foods and fluids, or pose an imminent risk of harm to self or child). ECT is also used to treat refractory MDD. For this patient with mild to moderate postpartum depression, a different treatment modality is the most appropriate next step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is appropriate for patients with postpartum blues, which typically manifests with mild depressive symptoms (e.g., depressed mood, lethargy, anxiety, exhaustion, insomnia) within 1 week of delivery and resolves spontaneously within 2 weeks. However, this patient's symptoms started 2 weeks after giving birth and have persisted for 4 weeks. Her presentation meets the criteria for MDD with peripartum onset, for which reassurance alone is not the most appropriate next step in management.

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer that can be used to treat postpartum psychosis and bipolar major depression, both of which can manifest with depressed mood. However, this patient does not exhibit any features of psychosis (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, paranoia) or manic symptoms (i.e., DIG-FAST symptoms). Lithium is not used to treat MDD with peripartum onset. Moreover, this drug should be used with caution in women who are breastfeeding because its effects on infants are unclear.

E) INCORRECT:

Hospitalization is indicated for patients with postpartum psychosis, which typically manifests with features of psychosis (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, paranoia), manic or depressed mood, severe insomnia, anxiety, and irritability within 2 weeks of delivery. Though this patient has depressive symptoms, she does not have features of psychosis. Hospitalization is also indicated in patients with MDD who have suicidal or homicidal ideations, which this patient does not have.
questions.hint: This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder (MDD), i.e., depressed mood, fatigue, insomnia, decreased appetite, anxiety, and feelings of guilt and worthlessness, which have been present for ≥ 2 weeks and developed within 4 weeks after delivery. This is consistent with MDD with peripartum onset.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of unusual behavior for the last 2 weeks. The patient has been more anxious since the birth of their child 1 month ago and has recently stopped breastfeeding. According to the husband, she wakes the child every night and takes him out in the garden for “moon baths.” She also tried giving unpasteurized milk and raw honey to the child despite her husband's warnings on several occasions. When asked about her behavior, the patient replies, “The earth spirits told me what's good for him, and I trust them.” She has a history of bipolar disorder but stopped taking her medication when she found out about her pregnancy. She appears agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an involuting uterus consistent in size with her postpartum date. She denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotic therapy is used to treat postpartum psychosis. However, this patient's hallucinations and agitation pose an imminent risk to the newborn and herself, so another step is more appropriate at this point before initiating antipsychotic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Mood-stabilizing therapy is used to treat bipolar disorder and postpartum psychosis. This patient has a history of bipolar disorder and stopped her medication during her pregnancy, which should be restarted. However, her hallucinations and agitation pose an imminent risk to the newborn and herself, so another step is more appropriate at this point before reinitiating mood-stabilizing therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Hospitalization is the most appropriate next step in management for patients with postpartum psychosis who are unable to care for themselves or their child, as is the case for this patient. Although hospitalization interferes with maternal-infant bonding, it reduces the risk of harm to the child. If the mother is allowed to spend time with her child, it should be under close supervision. Pharmacotherapy typically includes a combination of a second-generation antipsychotic and a mood stabilizer.

See “Differential diagnosis of peripartum mood disturbances” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) may be used as adjuvant treatment in the management of postpartum psychosis. However, CBT is typically only begun once psychotic symptoms have resolved. This patient still experiences psychotic symptoms, so CBT is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is recommended for postpartum blues, which typically manifest with mood changes, such as agitation. However, patients with postpartum blues usually experience mild depressive symptoms and do not have hallucinations. Furthermore, postpartum blues typically develop within 2–3 days postpartum and resolves within 2 weeks, whereas this patient's symptoms began 2 weeks postpartum.
questions.hint: This onset of bizarre behavior and hallucinations 2 weeks after giving birth, in combination with a history of bipolar disorder, is suggestive of postpartum psychosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes for a follow-up examination 3 months after beginning sertraline therapy for major depressive disorder. He takes the medication as prescribed and has started psychotherapy, but his mood has barely improved. The patient appears anxious and reports that he still feels sad and hopeless most of the time. He denies suicidal ideation. He is more tired than usual and often feels drowsy during the day. The patient has difficulty concentrating at work and has missed two important deadlines; he worries that he might soon lose his job. He is also concerned because he has continuously gained weight despite the initiation of sertraline. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 Ib); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient will most likely benefit from switching to which of the following pharmacotherapies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that causes sedation. An antidepressant without a sedative effect is necessary for this patient with drowsiness, lethargy, and difficulty concentrating. Moreover, if trazodone is used as monotherapy for MDD, high doses of trazodone are needed for an antidepressant effect and are associated with an increased risk of other side effects (e.g., cardiotoxicity, hypertension, priapism). Trazodone is primarily used in low doses for the treatment of insomnia or as an augmentation agent for the treatment of MDD if the patient has insomnia as a predominant symptom.

B) CORRECT:

The preferred first-line treatment for MDD is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) such as sertraline. Response to the antidepressant is assessed 6–12 weeks after initiating treatment. If the patient has minimal response to the initial therapy or experiences significant adverse effects, the antidepressant should be replaced with a different one by cross-tapering. The class of antidepressants that should be prescribed as a replacement depends on the type of depressive symptoms (e.g., hypersomnia vs. hyposomnia, hyperphagia vs. anorexia, weight gain vs. weight loss) and the side effects from the initial drug (e.g., SSRIs can cause drowsiness, anorgasmia, and decreased libido). This patient has lethargy, difficulty concentrating, and weight gain, and would therefore benefit from switching to bupropion, an atypical antidepressant that has a stimulant effect and is associated with weight loss. Bupropion also does not cause sexual dysfunction.

If the patient has a partial response to the initial antidepressant with minimal adverse effects, then augmentation therapy with another medication (e.g., a different antidepressant, an atypical antipsychotic, lithium, liothyronine) or with psychotherapy should be considered. If the patient has a complete response to the initial antidepressant prescribed for the first onset of a major depressive episode, the drug is continued for another 6–12 months (continuation phase therapy) after which it can be gradually tapered off if the patient remains in remission. Therapy beyond this period (maintenance phase therapy) is considered for patients with a history of recurrent, long-lasting, and/or severe major depressive episodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic and can be used as an augmentation agent if the patient has a partial response to the initial therapy. However, antipsychotics are not used as monotherapy for MDD.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), such as imipramine, can cause sedation, but also have other significant side effects, including anticholinergic effects (e.g., urinary retention, dry mouth), and are only used in exceptional cases. Switching to an antidepressant with a better side effect profile would be more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

In cases where the patient has minimal response to sertraline, switching to another selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as paroxetine, can be helpful. However, this patient is experiencing drowsiness, a possible side effect of all SSRIs. Moreover, paroxetine is an SSRI that can cause weight gain. For this patient, switching to another antidepressant class with a more favorable side effect profile is appropriate.

F) INCORRECT:

The anxiolytic buspirone is used primarily for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. There is no evidence to support the use of buspirone as either a monotherapy or augmentation agent in the treatment of MDD.
questions.hint: This patient with major depressive disorder (MDD) shows continued symptoms of depression (e.g., depressed mood, feelings of worthlessness, lethargy, difficulty concentrating, weight gain) and drowsiness (a possible side effect of sertraline) after 3 months of antidepressant therapy. Switching to a different antidepressant that can facilitate weight loss and that is less likely to cause drowsiness should be considered.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman returns for ongoing management of her depression. She began taking fluoxetine 20 mg daily 4 weeks ago. She reports some improvement in her mood, sleep, appetite, tension, and concentration that plateaued after 2 to 3 weeks. She then ceased to experience further improvement, and she continues to be distressed by diminished energy and a lack of pleasure in her life. She denies having any medication-induced side effects.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Increase the dose of fluoxetine to 30 mg daily
Stop the fluoxetine and begin a trial of duloxetine
Continue fluoxetine 20 mg daily and add mirtazapine
Continue fluoxetine 20 mg daily and add lithium

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, are first-line medications for moderate depression, particularly in outpatients and those treated by primary care providers. During the acute phase of depression, the goal of treatment is symptom remission. If a patient continues to experience persistent distress after starting treatment (as in this case), the antidepressant dose should be increased gradually until there is either relief of symptoms or emergence of intolerable side effects. Patients who are susceptible to side effects (e.g., patients with anxiety and older patients) may require slower dose adjustments, whereas those who are tolerating their medications with minimal side effects may prefer a more aggressive approach.

Fluoxetine is generally initiated at a dose of 10 to 20 mg daily and increased in 10- to 20-mg increments at intervals of 2 to 4 weeks. Given that this patient started fluoxetine at a dose of 20 mg daily but has persistent distress 4 weeks later, the most appropriate next step is to increase the dose to 30 mg daily. Continuing fluoxetine at the current dose would not be appropriate. The optimal maintenance dose can be sought after the acute phase of treatment, once she has gotten adequate relief from her depressive symptoms. This process can be enhanced by incorporating validated outcome measures into the ongoing evaluation of her depression.

If symptoms continue to persist after the initial dose adjustment, the antidepressant can continue to be increased up to the maximum daily dosage (80 mg daily for fluoxetine), with close monitoring to assure that the patient can tolerate it.

An adequate trial of an SSRI requires 4 to 8 weeks at an optimal dose. If a patient has an inadequate response to such a trial, the clinician should consider switching to a new antidepressant from a different class or combining two antidepressants from different classes. If the response is still inadequate, many augmentation strategies are available, including adding lithium, thyroid hormone, atypical antipsychotics, anticonvulsants, or buspirone.

Key learning point: In a patient who is tolerating a selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitor but has residual symptoms of depression, the most appropriate management is dose optimization over 4 to 8 weeks.

Given that this patient started fluoxetine at a dose of 20 mg daily but has persistent distress 4 weeks later, the most appropriate next step is to increase the dose to 30 mg daily. Continuing fluoxetine at the current dose would not be appropriate. The optimal maintenance dose can be sought after the acute phase of treatment, once she has gotten adequate relief from her depressive symptoms.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man reports fatigue, weight loss, constipation, disturbed sleep, loss of libido, vague aches and pains, and poor memory and concentration. His symptoms started almost 6 months ago, following a divorce from his wife, and have slightly reduced his levels of interest and productivity at work.
