The patient says his symptoms are associated with feelings of loneliness and guilty ruminations about his divorce. He denies having thoughts about wanting to die or harm himself. His score on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-9 is 25, indicating severe depression.
His vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend behavioral activation, prescribe daily exercise, and refer to a mental health provider for evaluation
Refer the patient to the emergency department for evaluation
Educate the patient and his family about the natural history of the illness
Refer the patient for individual psychotherapy
Initiate an antidepressant, see the patient regularly, and refer him for individual psychotherapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the initial presentation is of mild depressive symptoms (PHQ-9 score of 5 to 9), the appropriate intervention involves education of the patient and family, behavioral activation, and exercise.

B) INCORRECT:

If the presenting symptoms of depression are severe or chronic (a PHQ-9 score of 20 to 27), the initial recommendation is to provide the patient with antidepressants, see the patient regularly, and refer for psychotherapy. If the patient has thoughts or plans of suicide or homicide — or is unable to take care of himself or his family — he should either be referred to the emergency department or receive a same-day consultation with a psychiatrist or psychotherapist.

C) INCORRECT:

If the initial presentation is of mild depressive symptoms (PHQ-9 score of 5 to 9), the appropriate intervention involves education of the patient and family, behavioral activation, and exercise.

D) INCORRECT:

When the initial presentation is mild to moderate (PHQ-9 score of 10 to 19), treatment involves an antidepressant, psychotherapy, or both, as well as weekly contact to ensure adequate engagement. In mild-to-moderate levels of depression, psychotherapy can be as effective as medication; on some occasions, a patient will have a strong preference for one or the other, and it may be helpful to follow that lead.

E) CORRECT:

When treatment options are being considered for a patient with symptoms of depression, the primary goal is to achieve remission or to help the patient become symptom free (as indicated by a Patient Health Questionnaire-9 [PHQ-9] score of <5).

If the presenting symptoms of depression are severe or chronic (a PHQ-9 score of 20 to 27), the initial recommendation is to provide the patient with antidepressants, see the patient regularly, and refer for psychotherapy. If the patient has thoughts or plans of suicide or homicide — or is unable to take care of himself or his family — he should either be referred to the emergency department or receive a same-day consultation with a psychiatrist or psychotherapist. Insomnia, if present, may require additional treatment.

Key learning point: In a patient with severe depressive symptoms, the most appropriate management approach is pharmacotherapy.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old single man with idiopathic cardiomyopathy is tearful, indicates that he has felt “down” for the past 2 months, and says that he no longer finds pleasure in spending time with friends or his long-term girlfriend. He also reports a poor appetite, decreased concentration, and difficulty falling asleep. Some days, he wishes he were no longer alive, but he denies an active plan or intent to end his life.
The patient had a similar episode 2 years ago. Treatment with fluoxetine led to little symptomatic improvement, and he developed erectile dysfunction and nausea, even at a low dose of the medication. The patient is open to discussing medication options but is concerned about experiencing similar side effects again, especially sexual dysfunction.
Which one of the following medications is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline and nortriptyline are not considered first-line treatments for depression because they have anticholinergic effects that may be poorly tolerated. They also carry an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias and are therefore usually avoided in patients with cardiac disease.

B) CORRECT:

Antidepressants — specifically, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine — are the preferred first-line medications for treating moderate-to-severe depression. However, for patients concerned about sexual side effects, bupropion is an effective alternative.

Given that bupropion has a different mechanism of action than SSRIs — it inhibits dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake — it is a good choice for patients who have had minimal benefit from an SSRI in the past. This drug also causes less nausea, diarrhea, and sexual dysfunction than SSRIs. Given that the half-life of bupropion is relatively short, dosing may be easier with sustained- and extended-release formulations of this medication.

Key learning point: The most appropriate medication for treatment of moderate-to-severe depression in a patient who did not tolerate a selective serotonin-receptor inhibitor is bupropion.

C) INCORRECT:

The SSRI paroxetine is associated with a higher rate of sexual dysfunction than other SSRIs, so it would not be a good choice for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors, such as phenelzine, require dietary restrictions and carry drug-interaction risks; thus, they are not first-line agents.

E) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine is a dual-acting serotonin- and norepinephrine-reuptake inhibitor that is associated with moderate gastrointestinal side effects and a moderate risk of sexual dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man reports that he has felt depressed for the past 3 months. He awakens much earlier than usual, feeling fretful. He has low energy, poor concentration, and limited interest in his usual activities throughout the day. He also notes that since becoming depressed, he has had difficulty having sexual relations with his steady girlfriend, including decreased ability to obtain or maintain an erection and a decreased frequency of orgasms.
Which one of the following treatment strategies is most appropriate to restore this patient’s erectile function?

choices.text: Refer to urology for intracavernous alprostadil

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sildenafil should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Sex therapy should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

C) CORRECT:

Sexual dysfunction is likely a symptom of major depression in this young man, so treating the depression is the most appropriate first step. Bupropion is a good choice, because it is an effective antidepressant that does not typically cause sexual side effects or decreased libido. The antidepressant alone may solve the erectile dysfunction and the depression.

Bupropion is the best choice among the options listed, but psychosocial treatment would also be appropriate in this setting, usually in the form of cognitive behavioral therapy. Such treatment requires an ongoing commitment from the patient and involves finding an appropriate therapist with whom the patient can build a relationship. If the patient will accept it, a combination of medication and psychotherapy is generally more effective than either treatment alone.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment to restore erectile function in a patient with untreated major depressive disorder is an antidepressant with a low incidence of sexual side effects, such as bupropion.

D) INCORRECT:

Alprostadil should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine is an effective antidepressant but carries a higher risk for sexual side effects than bupropion.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man reports recent-onset erectile dysfunction characterized by diminished libido and difficulty obtaining an erection. He has a history of insulin-treated diabetes and depression, for which he sees a psychiatrist and therapist regularly. Three months ago, he started taking fluoxetine for his depression. He had surgery to repair a left inguinal hernia one year ago.
An affirmative answer to which one of the following questions would be most consistent with hypogonadism as a cause of this patient’s erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Have you needed to shave less often?
Do you lose your erection during intercourse?
Are you able to generate an erection with masturbation?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety often experience spontaneous morning erections.

B) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction has multiple possible causes in this case. Diabetes is associated with sexual dysfunction because of damage to nerves and small blood vessels. Depression can cause sexual dysfunction, as can its treatment. Fluoxetine, like all selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors, can reduce libido and impair erectile function. However, this patient could also have primary or secondary hypogonadism.

Diabetes, depression, and antidepressants are not typically associated with changes in secondary sexual characteristics, such as loss of body hair, facial hair, or muscle mass. A patient who responds affirmatively to a question about a reduction in shaving frequency should be evaluated for hypogonadism. It should be noted, however, that although a change in shaving frequency is quite specific to hypogonadism, it is not very sensitive; most men with established facial hair growth do not notice a change in such growth when they develop hypogonadism. Therefore, this patient should likely be evaluated further for hypogonadism with testosterone measurements regardless of his shaving frequency.

Key learning point: Symptoms of male hypogonadism include erectile dysfunction, loss of libido, less facial hair, and loss of muscle mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced sexual desire can be a feature of either hypogonadism or depression, so a question about desire or libido does not help distinguish the cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety are able to generate an erection with masturbation, but they may lose tumescence during intercourse.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety are able to generate an erection with masturbation, but they may lose tumescence during intercourse.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old divorced woman reports that she has had difficulty falling asleep each night for the past 2 weeks.
She is tearful and describes her mood as “low” for the past several months. She takes no pleasure from spending time with her grandchildren and has little desire to leave the house; she naps periodically during the day. Her energy, appetite, and concentration have diminished. She has lost 2.3 kg since her last visit. She sometimes feels she might be better off dead, although she has no plan to harm herself. She is not anxious and has not experienced elevated mood, paranoia, or hallucinations.
Her physical examination is unremarkable. Routine laboratory evaluation yields normal results.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Provide instructional materials about sleep hygiene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotic medications, such as aripiprazole, are not recommended for first-line treatment of depression, especially in a patient that does not have psychotic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Teaching good sleep hygiene is always sound practice, but it is not sufficient for treating insomnia in the context of a major depressive episode. Furthermore, depressive symptoms are likely to impair a patient’s capacity to assimilate or benefit from such teaching.

C) INCORRECT:

A sleep study is unnecessary in a patient whose symptoms suggest depression rather than a primary sleep disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

The benzodiazepine receptor agonist zolpidem is not a treatment for depression and is therefore not a good first choice for this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's constellation of symptoms — insomnia, depressed mood, markedly diminished pleasure, thoughts of death, and changes in appetite, energy, and concentration — is consistent with a major depressive disorder. The depression is her primary problem and should be the focus of treatment. The insomnia is secondary, but it helps guide the choice of antidepressant.

Any first-line antidepressant could be a reasonable option for treating this patient’s depression, but a sedating antidepressant such as mirtazapine has an additional advantage — it may give her a better night’s sleep. (Some antidepressants can make insomnia worse, a problem best avoided in this case.) As with any antidepressant, the medication’s advantages should be balanced against adverse effects. In addition to sedation, mirtazapine is commonly associated with increased appetite and weight gain.

Key learning point: The first step in treating insomnia in a patient who has symptoms of major depression is to treat the depression with a sedating antidepressant, such as mirtazapine.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man with a history of colon cancer in remission for the past 5 years presents with a gradually worsening mood.
Two months ago, he developed constipation and began ruminating on the possibility that it might be a sign of cancer recurrence. He has little appetite and has lost weight, which he takes as further confirmation that he might be dying. Despite resolution of the constipation, a normal colonoscopy, and reassurance that the constipation was not due to a cancer recurrence, he is sad and tearful and has been feeling hopeless. Around the same time that the constipation began, he started complaining of memory difficulties and began to isolate himself from family activities; because, he says, “I just don’t see the point.” He wakes every morning between 4:00 and 5:00 a.m. He is preoccupied with death but does not want to die and does not have suicidal thoughts.
He has no history of major depressive disorder or other psychiatric illness and is otherwise well.
Which one of the following treatments, if any, is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Common signs and symptoms of depression include reduced energy and concentration, early morning awakening, changes in appetite, weight loss, and somatic preoccupations. Subjective complaints of memory loss can be a feature of depression. In older adults, somatic complaints and worries are particularly common.

When cancer recurrence is a realistic concern, clinicians may be tempted to discount depressive symptoms as an unremarkable consequence of living with a life-threatening illness. However, this patient’s symptoms are consistent with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder, given their effect on his overall functioning.

Escitalopram is an accepted first-line pharmacologic treatment for depression regardless of age. It is a selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is reasonably well tolerated and associated with relatively few significant drug-drug interactions. The list of first-line depression medications is long. Evidence does not strongly recommend one agent over another. In addition to escitalopram, possible options include the following medications:

• another SSRI
• the serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) venlafaxine and duloxetine
• bupropion (a norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor)
• mirtazapine (an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist and 5-HT2 antagonist)

These medications have varied side-effect profiles.

Psychotherapy (including cognitive behavior therapy) is another effective treatment for depression. It can and should be discussed as part of the treatment recommendations, to explore if the patient is open to it. Combination therapy (medication plus psychotherapy) is more effective than either treatment alone.

Key learning point: Patients with cancer and other potentially fatal illnesses can develop depressive symptoms that significantly affect functioning and therefore require treatment. One reasonable next step for an older patient who develops new onset of significant depressive symptoms is to treat the depression with an antidepressant, such as the selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitor escitalopram.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), such as imipramine, may be used as later options in cases of treatment resistance but are not first-line treatments for depression. The anticholinergic, antiadrenergic, and cardiac effects of TCAs may be particularly problematic for older patients.

C) INCORRECT:

When cancer recurrence is a realistic concern, clinicians may be tempted to discount depressive symptoms as an unremarkable consequence of living with a life-threatening illness. However, this patient’s symptoms are consistent with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder, given their effect on his overall functioning.

D) INCORRECT:

Electroconvulsive therapy can be considered in older depressed patients if several psychopharmacologic treatments have been either ineffective or poorly tolerated.

E) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotic medications, such as quetiapine, do sometimes have an antidepressant effect on their own, but in unipolar depression, they are more often used for their augmenting effect. They are not considered first-line treatments for depression.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of obesity, type 2 diabetes (most recent glycated hemoglobin level, 7.5%), coronary artery disease, heart failure (most recent ejection fraction, 35%), hyperlipidemia, and hypertension presents for a routine follow-up visit. He reports that he started feeling depressed about 6 months ago, when he found that, due to shortness of breath, he could no longer do the physical activities that he used to enjoy. He has good emotional support from his wife and son, and they have encouraged him to seek treatment for the depression. When questioned, he reports no suicidal or homicidal ideation. His current medications are metformin, furosemide, carvedilol, lisinopril, aspirin, rosuvastatin, and a multivitamin.
On examination, he is afebrile. His heart rate is 76 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and his BMI is 34. Other than obesity and his mildly depressed demeanor, his physical examination is normal.
Routine laboratory testing, including electrolyte levels, is normal. An electrocardiogram shows a corrected QT interval of 500 msec.
Which one of the following medications is the best first choice for treating this patient’s depression?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine can cause a rise in blood pressure, especially at higher doses, and is therefore not ideal for a patient with hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Phenelzine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor, is a poor choice for initial treatment of depression because it can cause orthostatic hypotension, hypertensive crisis, and weight gain. It also requires patients to follow a sometimes inconvenient diet.

C) INCORRECT:

Although citalopram is also an SSRI, it has been associated with QT prolongation and is therefore contraindicated in this case. Fatal arrhythmia is relatively rare as a consequence of antidepressant treatment, but it is the adverse outcome most crucial to avoid. This patient has a corrected QT interval of 500 msec and should therefore not take any medication that would prolong the interval further.

D) CORRECT:

There is no one antidepressant that is best for all cardiac patients. The choice of medication should depend on the individual risk profile, including type of heart disease and comorbidities, and on patient preferences. In this case, as in many cases where there are multiple medical problems, there is no perfect choice.

Of the options listed, sertraline is best for this patient because, like other selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), it is associated with recovery of heart rate variability, reduction of inflammatory markers, improvements in endothelial function, and a reduction in platelet aggregation.

Although sertraline is the best option of those listed for this patient, there are still adverse effects to consider. All SSRIs can reduce sexual function, which may not be tolerable to the patient, and specific drug interactions must also be monitored. For example, sertraline may increase the effect of the beta-blocker carvedilol, and the combination of sertraline and furosemide can lead to hyponatremia.

Key learning point: The optimal pharmacologic therapy for depression in a patient with coronary artery disease, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, hypertension, and a prolonged corrected QT interval is sertraline.

E) INCORRECT:

The tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) amitriptyline is best avoided in patients with conduction problems because it can cause arrhythmias. In addition, TCAs are prone to cause orthostatic hypotension and have anticholinergic effects, like dry mouth and constipation, that are intolerable to many patients.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male college student reports several months of feeling “down in the dumps” most of the day, nearly every day. He has had difficulty concentrating at school and at home, which has interfered with his schoolwork and his ability to stay focused on tasks. He has been embarrassed publicly for his lack of preparation in class and feels anxious about his declining academic performance.
For at least a month, he has had difficulty sleeping at night and has had little interest in activities he normally enjoys. He feels guilty about his alcohol consumption, which consists of approximately two beers 3 to 4 times per week. He denies any thoughts of hurting himself or others and denies any perceptual disturbances.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Social anxiety disorder is marked by a persistent fear of social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others. Such social situations are avoided, causing significant social or occupational impairment. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance tends to persist, often lasting 6 months or more.

B) INCORRECT:

In alcohol use disorder, patients will report tolerance and withdrawal, difficulty controlling intake (e.g., being unable to cut back, drinking more than intended, continuing to drink despite knowledge of harm, spending a lot of time drinking), use of alcohol in hazardous situations (e.g., drinking and driving), cravings, or negative consequences as a result of alcohol use (e.g., failed role obligations).

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent depressive disorder is often difficult to distinguish from major depression, but (as the name suggests) it is characterized more by its persistence than its severity: Depressed mood for most of the day, on more days than not, for at least 2 years and without more than 2 months of relief during that time. Depressive symptoms (changes in appetite and sleep, low energy or self-esteem, poor concentration, or hopelessness) may or may not be as severe as in major depressive disorder during this 2-year period. A person with persistent depressive disorder may also have episodes of major depressive disorder during their illness.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, there is a persistent and marked pattern of inattention or hyperactivity starting before age 12, with impairment seen in two or more settings (e.g., at home, at school, at work, with friends).

E) CORRECT:

Major depressive disorder is characterized by at least 2 weeks of either depressed mood or anhedonia in combination with several of the following key symptoms:

• Significant change in appetite or weight
• Change in sleep
• Psychomotor agitation or retardation
• Low energy or fatigue
• Feelings of worthlessness or guilt
• Poor concentration
• Thoughts of death or suicidal ideation

This patient's constellation of symptoms — depressed mood, poor concentration, insomnia, anhedonia, and feelings of guilt — fulfills criteria for major depressive disorder.

Key learning point: Two weeks or more of depressed mood and/or anhedonia along with changes in weight, insomnia or hypersomnia, psychomotor agitation or slowing, fatigue, poor concentration, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, and recurrent thoughts of death are symptoms most consistent with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman with a history of tobacco use and hypertension who had a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) 2 months ago returns for routine follow-up. Her left ventricular ejection fraction at the time of the NSTEMI was 55%. Since then, she has experienced fatigue and low energy. She has resumed her usual exercise routine of attending spinning class twice weekly and reports that she usually feels tired but good after the class. She reports no recurrent chest pressure, dyspnea on extended exertion, or lower-extremity edema.
Her current medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, ticagrelor 90 mg twice daily, metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and rosuvastatin 20 mg daily.
Physical examination reveals a heart rate of 58 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 125/72 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 95% while she is breathing ambient air. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for repeat cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

There are multiple possible causes for this patient’s fatigue and low energy, but depression should be ruled out first. Depression is seen in about 20% of patients who are hospitalized for an acute myocardial infarction (MI) and has been identified as a risk factor for adverse outcomes after an acute coronary syndrome event. Among post-MI patients, those with untreated depression have a greater mortality risk than those without depression or those with treated depression. Screening for depression is therefore essential after an MI.

Patients can be screened for depression in many ways, but one of the most common is the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-2, which is a well-validated screening tool that is easy to administer because it includes only two questions — one asks about the frequency of anhedonia, and the other asks about the frequency of depressed mood, both within the past 2 weeks. If the patient strongly endorses either symptom (i.e., depressed mood or anhedonia nearly every day) or is moderately bothered by both symptoms, further questioning should be considered.

In this case, the patient already reports potential symptoms of depression and should therefore be asked more questions than the PHQ-2 provides, to explore whether her reported symptoms represent depression. A formal questionnaire that can be used for this purpose is the PHQ-9, which asks about nine major symptoms of depression: anhedonia, low mood, sleep abnormalities, low energy, changes in appetite, thoughts of worthlessness, difficulty with concentration, psychomotor slowing or restlessness, and suicidal thoughts.

Key learning point: When a patient presenting for follow-up after a recent myocardial infarction reports fatigue without any evidence of a medical cause, the clinician should assess for depression.

B) INCORRECT:

Exercise stress testing may be performed in high-risk patients, such as those with ST-segment elevation MI, to monitor for symptoms or arrhythmias before initiation of cardiac rehabilitation. Alternatively, if the clinician suspects recurrent symptomatic coronary disease, stress testing that includes an imaging modality would be a more appropriate study. Given that this patient does not have symptoms consistent with recurrent coronary disease and can engage in extended exertion without symptoms, there is no indication for exercise stress testing at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers such as metoprolol have long been thought to be associated with depressive symptoms, but apart from some old case reports, there is no evidence to support this. Discontinuing metoprolol would not be the best choice for this patient at this time, given that she is receiving cardiac benefit from the medication.

D) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram can assess recovery of left ventricular function after MI but is not necessary in this patient, who had normal left ventricular function at the time of the MI and has no signs of worsening cardiac function.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient does not have symptoms consistent with recurrent coronary artery stenosis; therefore, repeat cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not indicated.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man presents for routine follow-up. He is functionally independent, and his only medications are a statin for hyperlipidemia and acetaminophen as needed for occasional pain from knee osteoarthritis. At today’s visit, he reports that he has had increasingly depressed mood and feelings of worthlessness since he retired from his job last year, and he has also lost interest in participating in social gatherings. He reports no substance use or suicidal ideation.
His physical examination is unrevealing, and a cognitive test is normal. His score on the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-9 is consistent with moderate depression.
You discuss the diagnosis and possible therapeutic interventions with him. He expresses his understanding of the options and agrees to a mental health referral and pharmacologic therapy.
A review of his medical record indicates that he recently had normal routine blood testing, a negative sleep study, a normal hearing test, and an electrocardiogram showing normal sinus rhythm.
Which one of the following medications is the best initial pharmacologic treatment choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, can be used for symptoms of anxiety but would not be indicated for depression. In addition, it is highly anticholinergic and has been associated with falls and cognitive impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine, another commonly prescribed SSRI, is also best avoided because of its significant cytochrome drug metabolism interactions and long half-life, leading to an increased risk of drug-drug interactions.

C) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine, an atypical antipsychotic, would not be indicated in this patient given the absence of psychotic symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

The SSRI paroxetine is generally avoided in older adults because of its strong anticholinergic properties.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has major depressive disorder, which affects up to 5% of all community-dwelling older adults in the United States — and an even higher proportion of those who receive home health care (11.5%) or require hospitalization (13.5%). Depression is underdiagnosed and undertreated in older adults and may manifest similarly to cognitive impairment. Retirement is a major life change that can precipitate depression, financial stress, loneliness, and loss of identity for some older adults, although some may experience it as a positive change.

Older adults with depression may present with loss of interest in activities or with cognitive difficulty without necessarily demonstrating somatic symptoms such as changes in appetite or sleep. The Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-9 and the Geriatric Depression Scale are both validated tools that can assist clinicians with identifying and diagnosing depression as well as distinguishing depressive symptoms from cognitive impairment. However, these tools are not a substitute for diagnostic evaluation by a trained clinician. The differential diagnosis in an older adult with depressive symptoms should also include substance use disorders, sleep disorders, and metabolic abnormalities such as electrolyte disturbances; attention should also be paid to potential contributors such as hearing impairment.

Nonpharmacologic interventions for depression, including cognitive behavioral therapy and increased exercise, have been shown to be effective in older adults. However, some patients may have difficulty initiating these interventions, and medications may be needed. When pharmacologic treatment is indicated, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are first-line antidepressants in older adults because of their favorable adverse effect profile compared with other antidepressants.

Among SSRIs, sertraline has been shown to be effective in multiple high-quality studies and is favored because of its large dosing range (typically starting at 12.5–25 mg daily, with a therapeutic dose around 100 mg daily or more if needed) and its lower likelihood of prolongation of the corrected QT interval compared with other SSRIs.

Key learning point: Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are first-line antidepressants for older adults because they have fewer adverse effects than other antidepressants. Sertraline, in particular, is often favored over other SSRIs because of its large dosing range and lower likelihood of prolongation of the corrected QT interval.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman reports a consistently depressed mood for the past 2 to 3 years, with no improvements in mood for more than a few days at a time. She says she feels down most days and that her low mood, hopelessness, and low energy last the entire day. She reports occasional feelings of being better off dead but has never attempted suicide or had a plan for it. Her mood disturbances have started to complicate her relationships at home, and she has recently struggled to do her job well because she has difficulty making decisions. She reports having a normal appetite but difficulty falling asleep.
Physical examination and initial laboratory test results, including a complete blood count and thyroid-stimulating hormone levels, are normal.
Which one of the following features makes persistent depressive disorder a more likely diagnosis than major depressive disorder in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of symptoms for more than 2 years, with little or no remission
Feelings of fatigue lasting most of every day
Inability to fall asleep and stay asleep

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because both PDD and MDD are disorders on the depression spectrum, they share similar symptoms. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions can be present in both PDD and MDD and do not help to distinguish between the two diagnoses in adults.

B) CORRECT:

Major depressive disorder (MDD) and persistent depressive disorder (PDD) differ primarily in the duration and severity of symptoms. Symptom chronicity is one of the most common differences: PDD symptoms are typically present for at least 2 years without any period of remission that lasts longer than 2 months; MDD, in contrast, tends to involve depressive episodes (for at least 2 weeks) that have longer periods of diminished symptoms between them. In addition, PDD symptoms are often less severe than those of MDD.

Because both PDD and MDD are disorders on the depression spectrum, they share similar symptoms. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions, low energy or fatigue, insomnia or hypersomnia, and increased risk for suicide can be present in both PDD and MDD and do not help to distinguish between the two diagnoses in adults.

Key learning point: Persistent depressive disorder symptoms are typically chronic without long periods of remission, whereas major depressive disorder is episodic and characterized by longer periods of relative recovery between episodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Because both PDD and MDD are disorders on the depression spectrum, they share similar symptoms. Low energy or fatigue can be present in both PDD and MDD and do not help to distinguish between the two diagnoses in adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Because both PDD and MDD are disorders on the depression spectrum, they share similar symptoms. Increased risk for suicide can be present in both PDD and MDD and do not help to distinguish between the two diagnoses in adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Because both PDD and MDD are disorders on the depression spectrum, they share similar symptoms. Insomnia or hypersomnia can be present in both PDD and MDD and do not help to distinguish between the two diagnoses in adults.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old gravida 1, para 1 woman presents to clinic 3 weeks after a normal vaginal delivery. Her husband reports that she has been extremely depressed for the past 2 weeks. She has been chanting oddly since the second day of the baby’s life, but he cannot understand what she is saying. At times, she is inattentive to her personal hygiene and does not respond to the baby’s cries for feeding.
With a bland expression, she states that her breast milk is harming the baby. On further questioning, she says that her breast milk is poison and that her baby is going to die. She has no psychiatric history.
What is the most appropriate first step in treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe haloperidol, and advise the patient to return for follow-up in one week
Start fluoxetine, and schedule outpatient follow-up in 4 weeks
Recommend initiation of lithium, and advise the husband to remain with the patient at all times until her symptoms improve
Start lorazepam, and refer for urgent outpatient psychiatric evaluation
Arrange for secure transfer to the nearest emergency department for immediate psychiatric hospitalization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Regarding antipsychotics, there are limited data available on their concentration in breast milk. Among the newer, second-generation drugs, olanzapine, risperidone, and quetiapine are thought to have the lowest concentrations. Haloperidol has been used for decades in situations like this one. There is some limited evidence that it also produces low concentrations in breast milk. It does not appear to harm infant development. Postpartum psychosis is likely to impair the mother’s decision-making capacity, so most women will need a great deal of support to weigh the risks and benefits of breastfeeding in the setting of antipsychotic treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Antidepressants (such as fluoxetine and bupropion) have a role in the treatment of postpartum depression, but they are generally avoided in postpartum psychosis because of concerns that they could trigger mania, rapid cycling, or a mixed mood state. They may be used with caution if significant depressive symptoms are not improving in response to other treatments.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient does not have a history of bipolar disorder or other mental disorder, but some experts, noting the connection between bipolar disorder and postpartum psychosis, would suggest using lithium as a first-line treatment. In practice, either an antipsychotic or lithium may be initiated, but the second drug is often introduced quickly if dangerous psychotic symptoms persist.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are frequently used as an adjunct medication for the agitation, anxiety, and sleeplessness that often accompany psychotic episodes. In some cases, the clinician may have already prescribed benzodiazepines before the patient developed any psychotic symptoms, since disrupted sleep and anxiety can be the leading edge of a psychotic episode. Benzodiazepines are generally not considered first-line treatment for the underlying psychosis, but they may provide additional relief for the patient’s distress.

E) CORRECT:

This woman is exhibiting signs of postpartum psychosis, which is associated with elevated risk for suicide and filicide. Therefore, it is a psychiatric emergency requiring hospitalization and prompt treatment. The risk to the patient is great enough that her transfer from the clinic to the emergency department should be done securely.

Postpartum psychosis affects one or two of every 1000 mothers, typically within the first 2 weeks of the baby’s life. Symptoms include abrupt mood shifts (either depressed or manic), delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking, and bizarre behavior. Affected women may have thoughts of suicide or of harming or killing the baby — and in a significant number of cases, women act on these thoughts.

Many (if not most) cases of postpartum psychosis represent an episode of bipolar disorder. In some women, the psychosis may be the first episode of bipolar disorder, so there may be no psychiatric history. A personal or family history of mental illness increases the risk for postpartum psychosis.

Once the patient has been hospitalized, a combination of medications is often deployed to manage postpartum psychosis and agitation. However, starting these as an outpatient is not appropriate due to the high acuity of this condition. There is some disagreement among experts whether an antipsychotic or lithium should be used first.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment of postpartum psychosis is hospitalization.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old gravida 2, para 2 woman reports feeling exhausted and having difficulty concentrating 6 weeks after vaginal delivery of a healthy baby boy. She has diminished appetite, is not sleeping well, and has stopped breastfeeding because she is too tired.
She is frustrated because her house is a mess and the laundry is piling up, but she cannot find the energy to complete these tasks. She finds herself crying uncontrollably in the context of this frustration. She was an avid walker before and during her pregnancy but no longer enjoys it.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reassure the patient that her feelings are normal and common
Refer her to a program for learning coping skills

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Up to 85% of women experience a postpartum phenomenon known as the “baby blues.” New mothers can feel more emotionally sensitive and may cry more easily than usual. It is uncomfortable, but the ability to function as a mother is usually not impaired. Furthermore, this condition almost always goes away within a few weeks. Reassurance and understanding are appropriate responses in such situations. However, this patient is showing clear signs of depression and requires treatment with antidepressants, psychotherapy, or both.

B) INCORRECT:

The birth of a child always brings new stresses and pressures. In the case of a first child, parents are transitioning into an important, life-changing new role. A second child challenges parents’ coping skills further. For patients who are having difficulty with these transitions, it can be helpful to direct them to resources for learning parenting skills or more general coping skills. Parent education and skills training, however, would not be adequate responses to a patient who has developed postpartum depression. This patient is showing clear signs of depression and requires treatment with antidepressants, psychotherapy, or both.

C) INCORRECT:

No one antidepressant is considered more effective than another. In patients without any previous depression treatment, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as sertraline or fluoxetine, are typically used first and are often well tolerated. Antidepressants from other classes are equally effective if an SSRI either does not work or is poorly tolerated.

D) INCORRECT:

The birth of a child always brings new stresses and pressures. In the case of a first child, parents are transitioning into an important, life-changing new role. A second child challenges parents’ coping skills further. For patients who are having difficulty with these transitions, it can be helpful to direct them to resources for learning parenting skills or more general coping skills. Parent education and skills training, however, would not be adequate responses to a patient who has developed postpartum depression. This patient is showing clear signs of depression and requires treatment with antidepressants, psychotherapy, or both.

E) CORRECT:

Postpartum depression affects 7% to 15% of women in the first 3 months after delivery; for those with a history of postpartum depression, the incidence is 25% to 50%. Symptoms of postpartum depression are similar to depressive symptoms that occur in other contexts: depressed mood; tearfulness; feeling hopeless, worthless, guilty, irritable, or burdened; diminished energy or severe exhaustion; poor concentration; anhedonia; sleep disturbance; and appetite changes. The mother may have recurring thoughts about death or consider suicide. Difficulty caring for the baby is a common feature of the illness, as is excessive worry about or trouble connecting with the baby.

Rarely, in about 1 out of 1000 births, the mother becomes psychotic. She may have hallucinations (false perceptions) or delusions (false beliefs). This form of illness, called postpartum psychosis, is associated with bipolar disorder. It is dangerous to the mother and child and urgently requires treatment.

Several treatments have been proven effective for postpartum depression. Antidepressants and psychotherapy are first-line treatments. Treatment is most effective when the two are used in combination. No one antidepressant is considered more effective than another. In patients without any previous depression treatment, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as sertraline or fluoxetine, are typically used first and are often well tolerated. Antidepressants from other classes are equally effective if an SSRI either does not work or is poorly tolerated. Recently, the FDA has approved brexanolone and zuranolone for the treatment of postpartum depression. Their role in treating postpartum depression is not yet clear, with challenges to broad use including route of administration (continuous intravenous infusion for brexanolone) and cost.

Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy and interpersonal therapy) has been shown to be as effective as medication in some studies. These are good treatment options (where they are available), especially for patients who are reluctant to take medication. Exercise can improve mood, but it is not recommended as a sole approach for patients with moderate-to-severe depression. This patient is showing clear signs of depression and requires treatment with antidepressants, psychotherapy, or both.

Key learning point: The recommended class of medications for managing postpartum depression is selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors.

questions.text:
The father of a 14-year-old boy reports that his son has mood swings at home several times a month. The boy is described by his teachers as well prepared and a good student. He has several consistent friendships with other boys and regularly attends basketball practice.
When questioned, the boy states that his father's expectations of him are too high. He reports no use of illicit substances. His physical examination is unremarkable, except for facial acne. He has not lost any weight.
Which one of the following additional pieces of history would be most consistent with a diagnosis of depressive disorder in this patient?

choices.text: Self-report that he sometimes feels sad or depressed when he is alone but that he can “snap out of it”
Weekly arguments with his parents about a curfew
Interpersonal difficulties with a specific peer at school
Brief but intense anger toward a sibling that may include physical aggression
A recent decline in his grades and more frequent behavioral disturbances at home

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adolescents often experience a wide variety of moods in relatively short periods of time, including transient feelings of depression, irritability, or anger. However, these moods do not necessarily indicate depression or other psychiatric illnesses.

B) INCORRECT:

Adolescents often have arguments with their parents and demonstrate brief, physical aggression toward their siblings.

C) INCORRECT:

Interpersonal difficulties with peers are also common in adolescence.

D) INCORRECT:

Adolescents often have arguments with their parents and demonstrate brief, physical aggression toward their siblings.

E) CORRECT:

Adolescents often experience a wide variety of moods in relatively short periods of time, including transient feelings of depression, irritability, or anger. However, these moods do not necessarily indicate depression or other psychiatric illnesses.

A depressive disorder should be considered (or additional professional evaluation sought) if an adolescent has neurovegetative symptoms for at least 2 weeks (significant increase or decrease in appetite, changes in movement characterized by either slowing of overall movements or agitated movements, persistent feelings of guilt, low energy, poor concentration, increase or decrease in normal sleep, loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities, and suicidal ideation) or if he exhibits severe symptoms, reports any suicidal ideation or self-injury, or demonstrates dysfunction in multiple domains, including at school, with peers, and at home.

Of the options listed, only functional impairment in multiple domains — as demonstrated by a decline in grades at school and more frequent behavioral disturbances at home — would raise concern for a depressive disorder in this patient.

Key learning point: Depression can be distinguished from typical adolescent mood swings by the severity, duration, and impairment of function.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 8-year-old boy is brought in by his parents for irritability and recent changes in behavior. During the past month, his appetite has diminished, he is not sleeping well, and his academic performance has worsened. He now refuses to attend school. He has lost 2.3 kg since his last annual physical.
On direct questioning, the child is quiet, tense, and guarded.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Personality disorders are not generally diagnosed before age 18 and would not account for the marked change in this child’s behavior.

B) INCORRECT:

Children with an anxiety disorder often present similarly to their adult counterparts — namely, with frequent worry and functional impairment rather than irritability or aggression.

C) CORRECT:

Depressive disorders in children are associated with functional impairment. Diagnosing depression in young children can be difficult, as their symptoms may differ from those in adults or even adolescents. In children, irritability and sometimes even aggression are more likely presenting symptoms than sad mood or affect. In addition, depression in young children may initially manifest as new academic difficulties or refusal to attend school, and some children may present with somatic symptoms, such as headaches or stomachaches. Notably, if the child is extremely and explosively aggressive, then the clinician should consider diagnoses of pediatric bipolar disorder or disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. Furthermore, the patient’s irritability occurs in the setting of concurrent neurovegetative symptoms (poor sleep, weight loss, decline in appetite), which makes the presentation more consistent with an episode of major depressive disorder.

Key learning point: Unlike in adolescents and adults, a young child with clinical depression is most likely to present with an initial mood symptom of irritability.

D) INCORRECT:

The presentation of academic impairment or refusal to attend school should raise suspicion for attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, but that diagnosis does not best account for this child’s accompanying mood and somatic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) is a psychological disorder associated with severe recurrent temper outbursts (verbal or behavioral) that are out of proportion to the circumstances as well as inappropriate for the patient’s age and development. These outbursts occur in the setting of persistent irritability that is present nearly every day for most of the day, lasting one year or more with no period of symptom remission longer than 3 months. Furthermore, these symptoms must occur in two or more settings and must be noted before age 10; the diagnosis typically cannot be given before age 6 or after age 18. Finally, this diagnosis is mutually exclusive with the diagnoses of bipolar disorder, intermittent explosive disorder, or oppositional defiant disorder. Although this patient presents with irritability, the duration is insufficient for a diagnosis of DMDD.

questions.text:
The father of a 15-year-old boy reports that his son has had unusual difficulty in school this semester. He also notes that the boy has been "a little down” since his school vacation a month ago. The boy has lost 3.2 kg during the past 3 months but has a normal physical examination.
Which one of the following features would indicate the highest risk for a suicide attempt by this patient?

choices.text: Exposure to the suicide of a peer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Other risk factors for attempting suicide include the presence of a mood disorder, nonsuicidal self-injurious behavior (e.g., “cutting”), substance use, a family history of suicide, a previous suicide attempt, availability of firearms, loss of a loved one, the presence of family conflict or social isolation, and familiarity with peers who have either completed or attempted suicide. Although important, each of these factors is less consistently and predictably associated with suicide attempts than suicidal ideation is.

B) CORRECT:

Suicide is one of the leading causes of death among people aged 10 to 24 years. Most adolescents are willing to speak to a primary care provider about their mental health concerns, so these providers are essential in the early screening for suicide risk.

The most consistent and predictive risk factor for future suicide attempts and previously attempted suicides in adolescents is the presence of suicidal ideation. Approximately one-third of adolescents who report suicidal ideation attempt suicide.

A careful, direct clinical interview is superior to a patient questionnaire for assessing depression and other risk factors for suicide. Any patient who screens positive for depression should be further assessed for potential for suicidal behaviors.

Key learning point: In adolescents, the most critical predictor of future suicide attempts and completed suicides that can be identified on screening is the presence of suicidal ideation.

C) INCORRECT:

Other risk factors for attempting suicide include the presence of a mood disorder, nonsuicidal self-injurious behavior (e.g., “cutting”), substance use, a family history of suicide, a previous suicide attempt, availability of firearms, loss of a loved one, the presence of family conflict or social isolation, and familiarity with peers who have either completed or attempted suicide. Although important, each of these factors is less consistently and predictably associated with suicide attempts than suicidal ideation is.

D) INCORRECT:

Other risk factors for attempting suicide include the presence of a mood disorder, nonsuicidal self-injurious behavior (e.g., “cutting”), substance use, a family history of suicide, a previous suicide attempt, availability of firearms, loss of a loved one, the presence of family conflict or social isolation, and familiarity with peers who have either completed or attempted suicide. Although important, each of these factors is less consistently and predictably associated with suicide attempts than suicidal ideation is.

E) INCORRECT:

Other risk factors for attempting suicide include the presence of a mood disorder, nonsuicidal self-injurious behavior (e.g., “cutting”), substance use, a family history of suicide, a previous suicide attempt, availability of firearms, loss of a loved one, the presence of family conflict or social isolation, and familiarity with peers who have either completed or attempted suicide. Although important, each of these factors is less consistently and predictably associated with suicide attempts than suicidal ideation is.

questions.text:
A 3-week-old boy is brought in for a well-child visit. He was born at an estimated gestational age of 36 weeks and 3 days to a 36-year-old gravida 1, para 1 mother by low-transverse cesarean section. He had checkups twice during the first week of life and was doing well exclusively breastfeeding. He was back at his birth weight within 7 days after birth.
At today’s visit, the mother reports that she stopped breastfeeding a week ago. She felt that she could not keep up with the baby’s needs and that he was never satisfied at the breast. He now takes 60 to 90 mL (2 to 3 ounces) of a cow’s milk-based formula every 3 hours and has surpassed his birth weight by 300 grams.
The baby has a normal examination today; he is alert, awake, and well perfused. The mother, however, appears very tired and sullen; she has dark circles under both eyes and is on the verge of tears for the entire visit. She also notes pain in both breasts but has not had any fever, chills, or erythema of the breast skin.
What is the most likely reason that this mother stopped breastfeeding her baby?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low milk supply is a common reason that women stop breastfeeding, but it is unlikely to be the explanation in this case. The child was initially breastfeeding exclusively and was back at his birth weight within 7 days after birth, which suggests that the milk supply was sufficient for adequate weight gain.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this mother notes sore breasts, she has had no fever, chills, or breast erythema, making mastitis unlikely. Of note, women with mastitis do not have to stop breastfeeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Plugged milk ducts are rarely a reason that women stop breastfeeding. In fact, women with plugged ducts are encouraged to continue nursing or pumping to help unplug the ducts.

D) CORRECT:

Postpartum depression typically manifests more than 2 weeks after childbirth with symptoms such as anhedonia, insomnia, fatigue, guilt, hopelessness, loss of appetite, and a feeling of being overwhelmed. Postpartum depression affects up to 1 in 7 mothers and is more common in women who have a history of depression during or before pregnancy and in women who have difficulty breastfeeding. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening all women for depression during pregnancy and in the postpartum period.

Postpartum depression is a common cause of early cessation of breastfeeding and is the most likely cause in this case. The mother has several symptoms of postpartum depression and should be evaluated further.

Key learning point: Postpartum depression is a known risk factor for early cessation of breastfeeding.

E) INCORRECT:

A difficult latch is a common reason that women stop breastfeeding, but it is unlikely to be the explanation in this case. The child was initially breastfeeding exclusively and was back at his birth weight within 7 days after birth, which suggests that he was able to latch effectively.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male college student reports several months of feeling “down” most of the day, nearly every day. He has had difficulty concentrating at school and at home, which has interfered with his schoolwork and his ability to stay focused on tasks. He has been embarrassed publicly for his lack of preparation in class and feels anxious about his declining academic performance.
For at least a month, he has had difficulty sleeping at night and has had little interest in activities he normally enjoys. He feels guilty about his alcohol consumption, which consists of approximately two beers 3 to 4 times per week. He denies any thoughts of hurting himself or others and denies any perceptual disturbances.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, there is a persistent and marked pattern of inattention or hyperactivity starting before age 12, with impairment seen in two or more settings (e.g., at home, at school, at work, with friends).

B) INCORRECT:

Social anxiety disorder is marked by a persistent fear of social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others. Such social situations are avoided, causing significant social or occupational impairment. The fear, anxiety, or avoidance tends to persist, often lasting 6 months or more.

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent depressive disorder is characterized by depressed mood for most of the day, on more days than not, for at least 2 years. Depressive symptoms (changes in appetite, sleep, energy level; reductions in concentration, self-esteem, or hope) may or may not be as severe as in major depressive disorder during this 2-year period.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's constellation of symptoms — depressed mood, poor concentration, insomnia, anhedonia, and feelings of guilt — is consistent with major depressive disorder.

Key learning point: Two weeks or more of depressed mood and/or anhedonia along with changes in weight, insomnia or hypersomnia, psychomotor agitation or slowing, fatigue, poor concentration, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, and recurrent thoughts of death are symptoms most consistent with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

In alcohol use disorder, patients will report tolerance and withdrawal, difficulty controlling intake (e.g., being unable to cut back, drinking more than intended, continuing to drink despite knowledge of harm, spending a lot of time drinking), use of alcohol in hazardous situations (e.g., drinking and driving), cravings, or negative consequences as a result of alcohol use (e.g., failed role obligations).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is brought to the office by her husband because of unusual behavior for the last 2 weeks. The patient has been more anxious since the birth of their child 1 month ago and has recently stopped breastfeeding. According to the husband, she wakes the child every night and takes him out in the garden for “moon baths.” She also tried giving unpasteurized milk and raw honey to the child despite her husband's warnings on several occasions. When asked about her behavior, the patient replies, “The earth spirits told me what's good for him, and I trust them.” She has a history of bipolar disorder but stopped taking her medication when she found out about her pregnancy. She appears agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. She denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotic therapy is used to treat postpartum psychosis. However, this patient's hallucinations and agitation pose an imminent risk to the newborn and herself, so another step is more appropriate at this point before initiating antipsychotic therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Mood-stabilizing therapy is used to treat bipolar disorder and postpartum psychosis. This patient has a history of bipolar disorder and stopped her medication during her pregnancy, which should be restarted. However, her hallucinations and agitation pose an imminent risk to the newborn and herself, so another step is more appropriate at this point before reinitiating mood-stabilizing therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Hospitalization is the most appropriate next step in management for patients with postpartum psychosis who are unable to care for themselves or their child, as is the case for this patient. Although hospitalization interferes with maternal-infant bonding, it reduces the risk of harm to the child. If the mother is allowed to spend time with her child, it should be under close supervision. Pharmacotherapy typically includes a combination of a second-generation antipsychotic and a mood stabilizer.

See “Differential diagnosis of peripartum mood disturbances” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) may be used as adjuvant treatment in the management of postpartum psychosis. However, CBT is typically only begun once psychotic symptoms have resolved. This patient still experiences psychotic symptoms, so CBT is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is recommended for postpartum blues, which typically manifest with mood changes, such as agitation. However, patients with postpartum blues usually experience mild depressive symptoms and do not have hallucinations. Furthermore, postpartum blues typically develop within 2–3 days postpartum and resolves within 2 weeks, whereas this patient's symptoms began 2 weeks postpartum.
questions.hint: This onset of bizarre behavior and hallucinations 2 weeks after giving birth, in combination with a history of bipolar disorder, is suggestive of postpartum psychosis.

questions.text: Ten days after the vaginal delivery of a healthy girl, a 27-year-old woman is brought to the office by her husband because of frequent mood changes. She has been tearful and anxious since she went home from the hospital 2 days after delivery. She says that she feels overwhelmed with her new responsibilities and has difficulties taking care of her newborn because she constantly feels tired. She only sleeps for 2–3 hours each night because the baby wakes up multiple times to feed. Her husband says that she is afraid that something could happen to the baby. She often gets angry at him and has yelled at him when he picks up the baby without using hand sanitizer beforehand. She breastfeeds the baby without any problems. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows a labile affect with no evidence of homicidal or suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sertraline is an antidepressant that can be used to treat postpartum depression, which begins within the first 4 weeks after childbirth and can manifest with depressed mood, insomnia, and fatigue. However, to establish a diagnosis of postpartum depression, patients must have ≥ 5 SIGECAPS symptoms that last for ≥ 2 weeks. This patient's presentation and the duration of symptoms (8 days) do not meet the criteria for a major depressive episode; her symptoms are caused by postpartum blues, for which beginning sertraline therapy is not the most appropriate next step in management.

B) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy can be used to treat postpartum depression, which begins within the first 4 weeks after childbirth and can manifest with depressed mood, insomnia, and fatigue. However, to establish a diagnosis of postpartum depression, patients must have ≥ 5 SIGECAPS symptoms that last for ≥ 2 weeks. This patient's presentation and the duration of symptoms (8 days) do not meet the criteria for a major depressive episode; they are caused by postpartum blues, for which beginning cognitive behavioral therapy is not the most appropriate next step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Risperidone therapy can be used to treat postpartum psychosis, which most commonly develops within the first 2 weeks after childbirth and can manifest with depressed mood, insomnia, anxiety, and irritability. However, this patient does not have other typical features of postpartum psychosis, which include hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and bizarre behavior. This patient's symptoms are caused by postpartum blues, for which beginning risperidone therapy is not the most appropriate next step in management.

D) CORRECT:

Postpartum blues occur in up to 85% of women following delivery and typically resolve spontaneously within 2 weeks. Therefore, providing reassurance and making sure the mother has adequate support (e.g., from a family member) until the symptoms subside is sufficient. However, since postpartum blues can sometimes progress to major depressive disorder with peripartum onset (i.e., if at least 5 of the SIGECAPS symptoms are present and persist for more than 2 weeks), it is important to schedule a follow-up approx. 10 days after the diagnosis of postpartum blues in order to reassess the patient's mental state.

See “Differential diagnosis of peripartum mood disturbances” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Interpersonal psychotherapy can be used to treat postpartum depression, which begins within the first 4 weeks after childbirth and can manifest with depressed mood, insomnia, and fatigue. However, to establish a diagnosis of postpartum depression, patients must have ≥ 5 SIGECAPS symptoms that last for ≥ 2 weeks. This patient's presentation and the duration of symptoms (8 days) do not meet the criteria for a major depressive episode; they are caused by postpartum blues, for which beginning interpersonal psychotherapy is not the most appropriate next step in management.
questions.hint: This patient presents with mild depressive symptoms (tearfulness, anxiety, irritability, fatigue) and labile affect that started within 1 week of delivery and have continued for less than 2 weeks, which suggests a diagnosis of postpartum blues.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the office by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. The patient had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily because he is concerned about his memory lapses. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He often feels too tired to leave his room. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time, a blunted affect, and psychomotor retardation. Attention, concentration, and short- and long-term memory are impaired. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory results are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is indicated in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer dementia (AD). Patients with AD can present with impairment of daily life and, especially in early stages, show symptoms of depression. However, the onset of AD is usually insidious, with progression over ∼ 8–10 years. The memory of recent events is typically the cognitive domain affected first in patients with AD. For this reason, patients are typically not oriented to person, place, or time. Also, unlike this patient who is concerned about his memory loss, patients with AD are often not aware of their cognitive deficits.

B) CORRECT:

This patient meets 5 (anhedonia, sleep disturbance, diminished cognition, psychomotor changes, and low energy) out of the 9 diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD). In patients with late-life depression, cognitive deficits may resemble dementia (i.e., pseudodementia). Compared to patients with other types of dementia, patients with pseudodementia are more likely to be aware of and concerned about memory impairment. Cognitive deficits in MDD typically have a sudden onset and manifest after the mood symptoms (e.g., this patient lost interest in playing the piano several months ago). Treatment of the underlying depression, e.g., with SSRIs such as citalopram, may lead to remission of the depression and reversal of the cognitive deficits. In older patients in particular, different causes of dementia must be considered if memory impairment persists after appropriate treatment and an improvement in depressive symptoms.

See “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiplatelet drugs such as aspirin may be considered in patients with vascular dementia. This type of dementia may present with abrupt cognitive decline and stepwise deterioration. This patient has risk factors for vascular dementia such as hypertension and advanced age. However, his loss of interest, sleep disturbance, and psychomotor retardation cannot be explained by this diagnosis and warrant a different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

A cerebral shunt is the treatment of choice for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). While NPH typically manifests with impaired memory, other typical findings such as incontinence and ataxic gait are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

E) INCORRECT:

Memantine can be used in addition to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors in patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer dementia or vascular dementia. This patient's memory deficits could be explained by either of these dementia types, and depressive symptoms may occur in early dementia. However, his cognitive deficits are more likely to be caused by pseudodementia.
questions.hint: This patient's cognitive deficits are likely caused by pseudodementia.

questions.text: A 33-year-old single man with idiopathic cardiomyopathy says that he no longer finds pleasure in spending time with friends or his long-term girlfriend for the past 2 months. He also reports a poor appetite, feeling “down”, decreased concentration, and difficulty falling asleep. Some days, he wishes he were no longer alive, but he denies an active plan or intent to end his life. During a similar episode 2 years ago, he was treated with fluoxetine, which led to little improvement, and he developed erectile dysfunction and nausea. The patient is open to discussing medication options but is concerned about experiencing similar side effects again. Which one of the following medications is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline and nortriptyline are not considered first-line treatments for depression because they have anticholinergic effects that may be poorly tolerated. They also carry an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias and are therefore usually avoided in patients with cardiac disease.

B) CORRECT:

For patients concerned about sexual side effects, bupropion is an effective alternative to SSRIs. This drug causes less sexual dysfunction, nausea, and diarrhea than SSRIs. Given that the half-life of bupropion is relatively short, dosing may be easier with sustained- and extended-release formulations of this medication.

Key learning point: The most appropriate medication for treatment of moderate-to-severe depression in a patient who did not tolerate a selective serotonin-receptor inhibitor is bupropion.

C) INCORRECT:

The SSRI paroxetine is associated with a higher rate of sexual dysfunction than other SSRIs, so it would not be a good choice for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors, such as phenelzine, require dietary restrictions and carry drug-interaction risks; thus, they are not first-line agents.

E) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine is a dual-acting serotonin- and norepinephrine-reuptake inhibitor that is associated with moderate gastrointestinal side effects and a moderate risk of sexual dysfunction.
questions.hint: Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine are the preferred first-line medications for treating moderate-to-severe depression. The next best medication has a different mechanism of action than SSRIs — it inhibits dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake — and is a good choice for patients who have had minimal benefit from an SSRI in the past.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman comes to the office because of difficulty sleeping and increasing fatigue. Over the past 3 months she has been having trouble falling asleep at night. During this period, she has had a decreased appetite and a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. Since the death of her husband one year ago, she has been living with her son and his wife. She feels guilty because she does not want to impose on them. She has stopped going to meetings at the senior center because she no longer enjoys them. Her BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is tired, has a flattened affect, and her cognition is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Recommend relocation to a nursing home

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Notification of adult protective services becomes necessary if abuse and/or neglect are suspected. This patient's BMI is normal and physical examination has not revealed signs of malnourishment, dehydration, or physical abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

Recommending relocation to a nursing home could be indicated if the patient's son was unable to properly care for his mother or if there were signs of abuse and/or neglect (e.g., severe dehydration, low BMI), but this is not the case in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Cognitive-behavioral therapy can be helpful as an adjunct therapy in patients with MDD, because it can teach stress management, relaxation, and coping techniques, and may improve everyday functioning. However, patient assessment has to be completed beforehand.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient may benefit from mirtazapine therapy, a second-line treatment for MDD that would also cause her to gain weight and help improve insomnia due to its sedative effect. However, this patient requires proper assessment prior to initiation of antidepressive therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Suicide screening and assessment is indicated for all patients who display symptoms of MDD. The physician should inquire about suicidal ideation, intent, and plans. Appropriate management depends on the severity of these symptoms and ranges from close observation, psychotherapy, and pharmacotherapy to the involvement of the family and involuntary hospitalization.
questions.hint: This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (anhedonia, insomnia, loss of appetite, fatigue, and feelings of guilt) for ≥ 2 weeks, which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the office because of generalized fatigue for the past 3 months. During this time, his grades have declined in his college courses because he has had difficulty focusing on assignments and sometimes sleeps in class. He no longer plays the drums for his band and has stopped attending family events. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation, delusions, or hallucinations. His speech is slow in rate and monotone in rhythm, and his thought process is organized. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:
